TALK.START.PARA: —I table a supplementary explanatory memorandum relating to the government amendment which has been circulated. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 6, page 6, after subclause (5) insert the following subclauses:

PARA.TAB: "(6) National principles formulated under subsection (1), and revocations or variations of national principles under subsection (4), are disallowable instruments for the purposes of section 46A of the Acts Interpretation Act 1901.

"(7) If there are no national principles in force under this section, paragraph 11(2)(d) is to be read as requiring the Commission to make the recommendations on the same basis as the basis on which the Minister is, under subsection (2) of this section, required to act in formulating national principles (see paragraphs (2)(a) and (b)).".

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition supports the amendment moved by the government to give the national principles for the intrastate distribution of federal local government funding the status of a disallowable instrument. This amendment achieves the same effect as an amendment moved by the shadow minister for local government, Mr Bruce Scott, in the other place, which the government defeated on a division on that particular occasion.

PARA.TAB: I am glad the government recognises the good sense of what the opposition was proposing in the House of Representatives and has now adopted the amendment as its own. I thank the Australian Democrats for their recognition at an early stage of the need for this amendment. This support has no doubt contributed to the government's change of mind.

The objective of the amendment is very clear. The bill provides the federal minister with enormous personal discretion over the intrastate distribution of federal financial assistance to local governments. In the case of local road funding, the minister's discretion as to the interstate distribution of these funds is completely unfettered. The only limitation on the minister's power in respect of the distribution of general purpose grants is the requirement that the funds be allocated on a horizontal equalisation basis together with a minimum per capita requirement.

While the current draft of the national principles is similar to the arrangements already in place and, as I mentioned earlier in the second reading, have relatively little impact on the current intrastate funding distribution, the scope does exist in the legislation for the promulgation of principles which substantially alter this distribution. For example, depending on the criteria used, the result might be a shift in the rural urban split of funding or the allocation of funds on a regional basis.

There is a real potential that at some indeterminate time in the future Ros Kelly's whiteboard will be dusted off and brought back into active service. In the past, an unrestricted power to determine principles has provided the federal minister with a role in the disbursement to specific councils of special reserve local road funds.

For all these reasons, the coalition considers it appropriate that the principles should be a disallowable instrument subject to the full scrutiny of parliament. The government agreed to this arrangement at the local government ministers' meeting in October 1994 but failed to ensure it was incorporated in the original bill.

The amendment will provide parliament with an opportunity to examine the principles and, if it has concern about their content, to pass a motion disallowing them. The notice of motion to disallow must be given within 15 sitting days after the principles have been laid before either house. This process promotes transparency in the allocation process and retains some parliamentary oversight of the distribution of $1.1 billion in federal financial assistance grants to local government provided annually.

It is important that the bill is passed by parliament before 1 July to avoid the reallocation of local road funding which, under present legislation, will occur on that date. I trust the government will accord the bill a speedy passage through the other place today.

TALK.START.PARA: —To expedite that speedy passage, I will not reiterate the arguments that have been well expressed by Senator Tambling. I agree with Senator Tambling's analysis of the reasons for this amendment being proposed by the government. I also acknowledge and welcome the interpretation that Senator Tambling has given to this amendment. The government has acknowledged that the numbers are on the board, having had an indication of support from the Australian Democrats in this place for the amendment moved by the coalition in the lower house, and therefore has introduced the amendment here. We welcome that support and want to expedite the bill's speedy passage.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 16, page 15, at end of paragraph 16(3) (c), add the following word and subparagraph:

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment includes some element of, perhaps, an aide-memoire that the management of natural resources and the environment is inclusive in the process. I cannot see why anyone should not see that that is the way that people think about the whole process of arrangements between local government and other levels of government. It is a glaring hole that environment and the management of natural resources is not an assumed part of the agreement. We have not seen any evidence that it is. We are more concerned that it might be excluded because of the nature of the wording of the agreements. We think it is very important that these considerations are part of the bill. It does not force people, but it enables them to make that consideration based on those elements.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition opposes this proposed amendment by the Greens. As I indicated in the second reading debate, the bill already imposes a number of obligations on local councils without providing additional financial resources or any inbuilt strategy to assist with the meeting of those obligations. This amendment is just another step in this direction. It is obviously more of an afterthought than any carefully considered attempt by the Greens to ensure that a comprehensive and useful approach is taken to the issue of good environmental practice.

PARA.TAB: Local government would bear the burden without any additional Commonwealth assistance and without any guidance on precisely what is expected of councils. If there are concerns about environmental management by local governments, it is more appropriate that these concerns are pursued in the context of the myriad of general territory, state and federal environmental legislation already on the statute books. There is no reason why local government should be singled out in this way in legislation dealing with general purpose funding.

The reporting requirement contemplated by this objective is also extremely open-ended. I can envisage that the time needed to obtain the information would be measured in thousands of man-hours and would obviously be very costly with little or no demonstrable benefits.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Tambling for his comments. Local government is and always has been on the cutting edge in these particular issues, although local government is the one at the coalface, so to speak. We are creating problems when we enter into major arrangements which specifically exclude these issues as a basis of decision making.

PARA.TAB: If you were to ask local government representatives whether they are very much involved with management of natural resources and environment they would say yes. There is danger if we create documents like the Local Government (Financial Assistance) Bill 1995 and the Competition Policy Reform Bill 1995 and specify that only certain elements can be considered. We are not imposing something extra. We know that local government is involved in these issues, anyway. The act ends up being a vehicle by which these elements are excluded. That is extremely dangerous. It is not a valueless thing. It means that as a parliament you have imposed one set of values and you say, `These are more important than the others'. When you say `it should be left somewhere else', the mythical `somewhere else' is being pushed out. The way it is worded it means that—like the competition policy—the ability to consider this in the whole minutiae, or even in the whole picture of how decisions are made in relation to funding, gets squeezed out.

It does not mean that people have to do huge extra things in order just to be able to consider these elements because they do that anyway. The problem is that you will now have problems in doing this in good decision making. If we as a parliament are excluding these from good decision making, then it seems to me that we definitely will be blamed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did foreshadow at the second reading stage that the Democrats would be supporting these amendments which Senator Margetts at that stage intended to move. Our reasons for doing so I think were well explained by Senator Margetts. The fact is that local government is the sphere of government most directly able to influence and affect what happens to our natural resources and our environment.

PARA.TAB: By omitting references to how local government should be involved at that level, we run the distinct danger of setting a pattern of thought, as has been indicated by Senator Margetts, which allows the buck to be passed elsewhere. Of course, the `elsewhere' in this case does not exist. The responsibility lies directly with local government, and that should be acknowledged in all legislation which has any capacity to influence how we see the responsibilities of local government.

The greatest example of omission is that horrendous package that recently passed through this place, much to our disgust—the competition policy bills. In the first instance, local government in many parts was ignored by that legislation. I think it is absolutely crucial that we continue to assert the proper role that is played by local government.

This is an attempt by Senator Margetts to ensure that that sphere of government is properly acknowledged, that its role is properly acknowledged. I think, for the sake of consistency, we should be doing this throughout our legislation. Therefore, we support the attempt in this piece of legislation to do just that. In no way do I accept the reasons that have been provided by Senator Tambling for not agreeing to these amendments.

PARA.TAB: "(4) The Minister must cause a copy of each report to be laid before or supplied to, as the case may be:
(a) each House of the Parliament;

This amendment perhaps states the obvious. It should be that reports are provided to various levels of government. This is legislation about local government, and one would think that it would be necessary to provide information to local government.

PARA.TAB: We have been told in our briefings, `Of course we'll provide information to local government.' There are several hundred of these organisations throughout Australia, but there is no indication that this reporting provision is a requirement. That is a problem. We are putting in legislation which does not require us to keep informed the level of government on which we are legislating.

Therefore, I believe it is necessary to state the obvious and, therefore, each house of parliament will be provided with a copy of the report and the local government ministers conference will be advised and each body representative of local government—and yes, there are several hundred—also will be advised of the outcome. That seems to be the least we can do. If we, as a federal government, feel that we are right to produce legislation about local government, which does not necessarily fully involve local government in putting it together, the very least we need to do is make a legislative commitment to keep that level of government fully informed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition opposes this amendment. The report which the minister is required to table on the operation of this legislation will, like all parliamentary reports, be publicly available. It is not necessary and would not be usual to include in the bill a provision mandating its supply to other parties.

PARA.TAB: As a result of amendments moved by the opposition, which were accepted by the government in the House of Representatives, the bill already requires the minister to consult with the states and local government in the preparation of the report. The Local Government Ministers' Conference would be the natural forum for discussion of the report both before and after its publication. There seems little point in formalising distribution arrangements in the bill. The Australian Local Government Association is represented at the conference.

TALK.START.PARA: —In fully supporting this amendment, I have a slightly different attitude to it. Perhaps one of my reasons is idiosyncratic, and I apologise if that is the case, but I think there are other people who would agree with my proposition that the mandate, as Senator Tambling described it, for the supply of the report to other bodies implicitly recognises those other bodies, just as it recognises the requirement to report to the Local Government Ministers' Conference.

PARA.TAB: I am suspicious about that particular style of conference. The COAG style of event has recently given us quite a number of packages of legislation which have been endorsed by and negotiated at such conferences, usurping the role of this parliament. To further validate that particular style of government undermines the democracy of our system.

I would prefer to see the information chain strengthened by requirements to report back to the bottom end of the decision making process, the area which is closer to the bodies which will be affected by these decisions. We have had far too many examples recently of negotiations being made at a sophisticated level beyond the influence of the affected parties. That is quite undemocratic. The result is presented almost as a fait accompli to this parliament, denying an opportunity for us to amend or influence. It is for those reasons in particular that I am entertained by this particular amendment. It works against that trend. I am pleased to see that and I fully support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —To back up what Senator Bell has said, I remind the Senate, for all the local government ministers' conferences, how much reminding people need of the respect there is for local government in, say, Victoria—
—How little respect!

—I meant it ironically—and in Western Australia, where the City of Perth was dissolved by a coalition government without consultation with the council or with the people living in the area, and how planning decisions, if there is a buck to be made, can be and have been overruled by local government ministers, and how much contempt there is by some state governments for legitimate and democratically elected local government.

PARA.TAB: Once again, it is convenient for both state and federal governments because currently there is no mention of and no rights or independent existence afforded to local or regional government within our constitutional statement. Therefore, what we see here is a convenient and cosy operation by which federal and state governments can negotiate between them what is appropriate to pass on to local government.

The obligations, it seems, are one way. There are obligations of reporting from local government mostly to state government, but there is also quite a large amount of obligation for local government to account for all its programs to federal government. More and more the federal government is wanting to be prescriptive as to what local government does.

Yes, I think there should be standards and that local governments ought to be rewarded for exceeding those minimum standards but, more and more, the benchmarking can and should be worked out between those people who know what the real issues are. The example I gave last night was of waste management, where we have the conceit of state and federal governments working out together what appropriate benchmarking there should be for waste management, as well as perhaps for resource management and all those other things that are specifically the work of local governments.

We are being given glib assurances that it will be okay and that the Local Government Ministers' Conference is the appropriate body, or the Local Government Association. That is fine, but they are not particularly highly resourced bodies. It seems to me that, unless you provide a legislative mechanism, later on you may have state governments once again negotiating with federal government as to the appropriate form of communication on these issues. I think that is totally inappropriate.

If we have the conceit to specify how these relationships should be with local government then, along with those obligations that we are putting into these kinds of bills, there should be some commensurate rights. But we are not doing that. The federal and state governments have worked it out all one way—or mostly one way—so that there is no mention of an obligation by the federal government to provide information to that very level of government which it seems convenient for both state and federal government to use their power under the constitution to stomp over, or do whatever they like with.
The other night we had the statement that local governments belong to state governments. Is that really the belief?

TALK.START.PARA: —Local government is a creature of state government.

—You create them. You can destroy them. The reality is that every part of Australia belongs to a local government and those people who are involved with local government do not think they are a margin. It is not a margin; it is not a little group; it covers the whole of Australia—it is just a different level of government.

PARA.TAB: All we are saying here is that, as part of this arrangement, there is an obligation—for once—on the federal government to report to local government. That means the state governments cannot decide that it is not the role of the federal government to decide how it will communicate or to whom it will communicate within the state and decide whether or not it will pass on that information. There is at least one tiny obligation on the federal government to communicate its decisions about local government to local government—for heaven's sake! As I said, the federal government—or we—will be blamed for this, in terms of the sheer audacity of our producing legislation for local government which gives no legislative commitment for information to be passed on to the levels of government that we tell how to operate.

The statement read as follows—

SPEECH.PARA: On 3 March 1994, the following matter was referred to the Committee of Privileges on the motion of the Deputy Chairman of the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, Senator Vanstone:

Whether there was an unauthorised disclosure of a submission to the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority, whether a contempt was committed by the disclosure, and whether there is any remedy for that disclosure.

The matter was referred as a result of a complaint to the National Crime Authority Committee by Mr L D Ayton that a submission he had made in confidence, under cover of a letter of 29 May 1991, had been disclosed without authority, had been referred to in both houses of the South Australian Parliament, and had been tabled in the South Australian Legislative Council.

The reference before the Committee of Privileges involved matters of high principle. The submission had been received by the NCA Committee in camera and its unauthorised disclosure was therefore proscribed under the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987. In addition, public disclosure of the submission and the accompanying letter had occurred in both houses of a state legislature, under parliamentary privilege. The Committee, taking into account advice on this element of its reference, accepted that it was constrained in examining members of that legislature as to the source of the documents.

The Committee had before it documents of the NCA Committee, setting out that Committee's attempt to discover the source of the disclosure. The NCA Committee received assurances from all members and staff of the Committee at the relevant time that they had not disclosed the documents, and also received a letter from the present South Australian Attorney-General drawing attention to the limitations on its examination of the matter.

Notwithstanding the comprehensive investigation by the NCA Committee, on receiving the reference the Committee of Privileges considered it necessary itself to attempt to discover the source. Accordingly, it sought and received advice from all members of the National Crime Authority Committee at the relevant time, and from the members of the South Australia legislature involved in the disclosure. It also sought information from a former journalist who, it was alleged in an anonymous telephone call to the NCA secretariat, had received the documents and had passed them to state members, and comment from the South Australian Attorney-General in the previous government, who had taken a continuing interest in the matter.

All National Crime Authority Committee members denied knowledge of the disclosure. The South Australian Attorney-General, the Premier and the Deputy Premier of South Australia did not make substantive responses to the Committee of Privileges; and the journalist concerned denied that he had published the documents to any other person. The Committee believes it has exhausted all reasonable possibilities as to the source of the disclosure.

The Committee regards the improper disclosure so seriously that it has decided to make a finding that improper disclosure of the submission and covering letter has occurred, and that this disclosure constitutes a serious contempt. It emphasises that it been unable to establish the source of the improper disclosure, owing particularly to the constraints on its capacity to examine members of the South Australian legislature responsible for publishing and referring to the two documents under the privilege of each House of the South Australian Parliament.

The Committee also recommends that, if the source of the improper disclosure is subsequently revealed, the matter again be referred to it, with a view to a possible prosecution for an offence under section 13 of the Parliamentary Privileges Act 1987. This Committee has never before taken the step of recommending that an offence should be prosecuted under the Parliamentary Privileges Act rather than through the Parliament's own contempt powers. The Committee considers the offence of such gravity, however, that action of this nature would be warranted.
I commend the report to the Senate and seek leave to continue my remarks later.

SPEECH.PARA: On 18 November 1993 the following matter was referred to the Committee of Privileges on the motion of the Chairman of the Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, Senator Bruce Childs:

Whether Dr Philip Nitschke was threatened with, or was subjected to, any penalty or injury on account of his evidence to the Standing Committee on Industry, Science, Technology, Transport, Communications and Infrastructure, and, if so, whether any contempt was committed by any action taken in relation to Dr Nitschke.

On 20 July 1993, Dr Philip Nitschke appeared before the Senate Industry Committee and gave evidence on behalf of the Medical Association for the Prevention of War (MAPW) in relation to that committee's inquiry into disaster management. His evidence on behalf of the MAPW concerned the preparedness of the Royal Darwin Hospital for any nuclear accident. Dr Nitschke, who has a Ph.D in physics, was at the time employed as a Resident Medical Officer at the Royal Darwin Hospital.
A brief account of the Senate Industry Committee's hearings was given on the ABC news at six o'clock that evening, and again at seven o'clock.

On that same evening, that is, 20 July 1993, the Minister for Health and Community Services, the Honourable Mike Reed, issued a press statement, responding to the news item. In the statement the minister defended the RDH's approach to responding to radiation accidents. He went on to criticise Dr Nitschke's "continued attacks on Royal Darwin Hospital" and concluded with the following statement:
If Dr Nitschke does not like the situation, I have no doubt that RDH will be able to scrape by without him.

On 14 August 1993, Dr Nitschke advised the Senate Industry Committee that the press statement had disadvantaged him. He expanded on his concerns in a later letter, advising that he had been officially notified that he had not been selected for employment for the 1994 year—a decision without precedent.
The Senate Industry Committee considered the matter and the Committee of Privileges received the reference on 18 November.

As in all matters of this nature, the issue the Committee was required to determine was complicated by the climate in which the incident had occurred, involving in particular the relationship between Dr Nitschke and other Resident Medical Officers, on the one hand, and senior hospital and health administration on the other.

The Committee has examined a substantial number of documents, most of which have been tabled with this report, and has heard evidence from relevant parties. During its hearings, the Committee received certain original documents. Following Senate consideration of this report, the Committee intends to seek authority from the Senate to return the original documents to the Northern Territory Government.

After due consideration of the evidence, the Committee has not been able to establish sufficient connection between Dr Nitschke's appearance before the Senate Industry Committee, and his failure to be offered a contract following first round consideration of Resident Medical Officer appointments to the RDH for 1994 and subsequent events, to make a finding that any contempt of the Senate was involved. The formal finding contained in paragraph 2.36 of the report reflects this conclusion.

The committee has, however, made critical comments about the administrative handling of this matter. The Committee continues to emphasise its concern about organisations' overreaction to public comment by officers and emphasises again, as it has in previous reports, that all public servants have the civil right to participate in matters of community interest provided that their private participation is not in conflict with statutory obligations.
I commend the report to the Senate and seek leave to continue my remarks later.

PARA.EMPHASIS: RESPONSE BY MS YOLANDA BROOKS AGREED TO BY MS BROOKS AND THE COMMITTEE OF PRIVILEGES PURSUANT TO RESOLUTION 5(7)(b) OF THE SENATE OF 28 FEBRUARY 1988

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to raise a matter of concern to me in relation to two speeches by Senator Ian Macdonald in the Senate on 18 November 1993 and 28 June 1994.
I wish to seek redress under the Resolution of the Senate of 25 February 1988 relating to the protection of persons referred to in the Senate (Privilege Resolution 5).
I apologise for not submitting a response earlier but I was not aware that I could do so.

My concerns relate to references by the Senator to the dismissal of the Shire Clerk of the Whitsunday Shire Council in Queensland. The Senator revealed the content of affidavits that are still in the jurisdiction of the courts. The affidavits referred to were filed in the Supreme Court relating to reasons why four councillors moved to terminate my position. The hearing is still pending. The purpose of the court hearing was to determine whether or not my position was terminated for being a "whistleblower".
The following is a brief history of events which are pertinent:
1.I was appointed by the Whitsunday Shire Council as Shire Clerk in September 1992, commencing duties on 16 November 1992.
2.I was selected from 45 other applicants for the position and I was the only woman applicant.

3.I am a qualified Municipal Clerk and have been since 1971. I hold the Clerk's Certificate for Victoria, New South Wales and Queensland. I am a member of the Institute of Municipal Management, member of the International City Managers Association and hold a Continuing Programme Development Certificate. I have been awarded by the Institute of Municipal Management two overseas study fellowships; one was to study office automation extensively throughout the USA and the other was to study occupational health and safety legislation throughout Australia and New Zealand. I have also studied garbage disposal throughout China with the Australia China Foundation Society.

4.I have held various positions in Local Government since 1971: Chief Administrative Officer, City Accountant for 7 years, Deputy Town Clerk for a period over 11 years; assisted the Chairman of the Local Government Commission in Melbourne in relation to research into feasibility studies of amalgamation proposals of councils, and more recently Shire Clerk and Chief Executive Officer.

My principal employers have been the City of Collingwood in Victoria—17 years, the Local Government Commission, Victoria—4 years, the Shire of Narrabri, New South Wales—approximately 2 years, and the Whitsunday Shire Council from November 1992 to the present.
The above is a list of all my employers since commencing my career in local government. My position has never been terminated prior to 12 July 1993.
A brief account of events between 1992 and the present will I believe assist.

Shortly after commencing with the Whitsunday Shire Council I was required to investigate the disappearance of the pecuniary interest register. This investigation included internal investigations and led to police investigations culminating in my alerting the Criminal Justice Commission in my capacity as Shire Clerk. Whilst this matter was ultimately resolved it precipitated the beginning of political, administrative and internal problems which have plagued me ever since.

There has been ongoing and continuing contact with the Criminal Justice Commission (C.J.C.) over a number of matters during my period of employment. The matters which were reported to the C.J.C. all related to pecuniary interest.

The series of events mentioned above culminated in four councillors moving to terminate my position on 12 July 1993. What followed was industrial action, intervention by the Criminal Justice Commission, Minister for Local Government, the Attorney-General and other legal intervention which is still ongoing.
1.On 18 November 1993 Senator Ian Macdonald said:
"The council voted, for reasons I will not go into, to dismiss the shire clerk because members of the council were not able to work with her, and for other reasons". (Senate Hansard, p. 3121)
This comment is damaging to my reputation. This is particularly so when it is read in the context of the speech as a whole.
2.On 28 June 1994 Senator Ian Macdonald again referred to the matter (Senate Hansard, pp. 2186-2188).

I do not believe that the Senator's version of the circumstances is an accurate reflection of the situation. The revealing of the content of the affidavits by my opponents prior to the court hearing has been damaging to me personally and professionally. It has been an attempt to prejudice my position but it does not reflect the extraordinary circumstances that existed at work.

The speech on 28 June 1994 has given an opportunity for a local paper to publish the transcript verbatim from Hansard. It took two full pages on 6 July 1994, all page 1 and 3. There was also a front page Editorial on 13 July 1994. This exercise is particularly interesting when it is known that one of the persons who gave an affidavit along the lines mentioned was the Editor of the Whitsunday Times.
The allegations against me are without basis in fact. The publication of the material has had direct detrimental impact on me.

By making the affidavits of my opponents public it has no doubt affected the public perception of my professional credibility and has done irreparable damage to my future career in local government or indeed any future employment prospects I may have had. The affidavits referred to portray a completely different situation to that which pertained at work, the seniority of my position and the extent and degree of my responsibility as the Shire Clerk.
I have high moral expectations and am an extremely hard working individual. I find the insinuations totally offensive.
Senator Ian Macdonald's remarks in relation to my general competence and unwanted sexual advances were completely unnecessary and unwarranted.

The comment "dispute between elected councillors and the Shire Clerk" implies that there was a problem between "all" councillors and the Shire Clerk. This statement is not true. The Shire Clerk had the support of 5 of 9 councillors and all indoor and outdoor employees, as well as a good part of the community. This was witnessed by "all" employees going on strike etc. Therefore, reference to the "council" when the council was so divided is misleading.

Reference to the campaign of smear and innuendo is exactly what these ex-councillors are doing to me . . . the opportunity that Senator Ian Macdonald has given these persons by revealing their affidavits in the Senate pre-empts the decision of the court. Indeed even though the court may find in my favour the adverse, negative publicity has irrevocably damaged my credibility, and caused exceptional private hardship financially, emotionally, physically and socially. The statements by Senator Ian Macdonald are incorrect and the publication of his speech in the local paper, the Whitsunday Times, is damaging to my proven reputation as an honest and hard working person.

During the period March 1994 to May 1994 negotiations between council and my solicitors continued in relation to settling outstanding matters. The transcript of the Senator's speech in the Whitsunday Times inflamed the situation, new councillors were embarrassed, it tarnished their view and alienated them in some way which was apparent in the manner some of them spoke to me.

In carrying out my duties I did no more or less than any other person in my position was required to do according to law. It is my impression that one reason I was appointed was because certain councillors felt that they could "bully" me to be a "rubber stamp" rather than what was required from a professional Shire Clerk.

In summing up, Senator Ian Macdonald has no personal knowledge of this council's procedures or operations. He does not know me personally, nor has he had discussions with me. He has no direct knowledge of my performance as Shire Clerk. He has relied on biased opinion and secondhand information. No attempt has been made to substantiate the allegations levelled against me mainly by former councillors who were subsequently not elected at the last council elections held in March 1994.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats have no objection to the government amendments. I just wish to raise a couple of points that came up in discussions on the Customs, Excise and Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1995, and I refer to the submission presented to the Senate Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs by the New South Wales Council for Civil Liberties. The council was concerned to ensure that, whenever body searches are undertaken, people are informed of their legal rights. I understand that there are provisions in the legislation, but very often it has been found that the customs officers concerned with the implementation have not been fully trained and are not fully aware of the procedures that they should be following.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats believe in the general principle that people must be informed of their legal rights. These rights include that the person has the right to refuse consent to the search, the person has the right to have the matter of a personal search referred to a judicial officer, the person has the right to insist that he or she be examined by a person of his or her own sex and, in the event that the search is a cavity search, the person must have the search conducted by a qualified medical practitioner. The Australian Democrats urge the government to ensure that, when these provisions that are the subject of this amendment bill are put into implementation, the staff of the department are properly informed and trained to observe the conditions that are imposed in these areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all, there is already provision in the act for the questions that you raise.
—I understand that.

—Fine. You quite rightly raised the issue about training for staff in relation to the new search and seizure legislation which we are now dealing with. I just want to give some information to the Senate to show that Customs is responding to these very important issues.

PARA.TAB: On 22 May a working party was formed in Canberra to prepare customs officers for the new search and seizure legislation. Members of the working party were drawn from central office, regions and the CPSU. Part of the working party's responsibility was the preparation and delivery of training programs to ensure that all relevant staff were equipped to use the new legislation and given adequate training in its provisions.

Regional training commenced on 19 June and consisted of, firstly, in-depth one- and two-day training packages targeted at those officers likely to use the new provisions on a regular basis and, secondly, an awareness package for staff who may have some peripheral contact with the legislation. There is an ongoing commitment to the training of staff after the enactment of the new legislation—particularly for those officers identified as belonging to areas where the use of search and seizure warrants is required. An awareness video is also being prepared to assist with this training. To date, 279 customs officers have been provided with in-depth training, and a further 321 customs officers provided with awareness training.

Customs officers from all regions, with the exception of the Northern Territory, have received training. Training of the Northern Territory officers will be carried out on 4 and 5 July. Key personnel from all district offices have also been included as part of this training program.

A 24-hour help desk has been established to provide expert assistance to customs staff on the application of the new draft legislation. Operational areas, including Northern Territory staff, can utilise the services of the help desk to ensure correct interpretation and receive clarification as necessary. Initially, the help desk will operate nationally out of Canberra but, as regional expertise develops, this responsibility will be taken over by the investigations branch in each region. The Customs Service has responded very strongly—and with my strong encouragement. It is not just a matter of carrying the legislation; it is a matter of the officers being trained so that the procedures are clearly understood, particularly the very sensitive matters of people being asked to comply with strip searches, body searches or internal searches.

The procedure leading up to someone being requested to take part in an internal search is extremely thorough. It does involve a check that it is not just a capricious decision of some staff member to say, `We would like to conduct one of these sorts of searches.' I can assure you, Senator, it has always been at the back of my mind that, as far as possible, there should be correct, simple, step-by-step procedures that can always be evaluated and monitored to ensure that the rights of individuals are protected to an extent that is acceptable in a modern society, within the context that we want to protect the borders of Australia from the importation of illegal and prohibited products and material.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the minister for his information and his assurance. The comments made and the concerns raised were not entirely raised in a vacuum. We had an incident not long ago when a 24-year-old Taiwanese woman was strip searched by customs officers at Sydney airport. That woman suffered a breakdown and had to be admitted for hospital treatment. Her clothes allegedly were torn by customs officers as the woman insisted that she had done nothing wrong and did not deserve to have her privacy violated. I simply raise that example to show that the concerns raised are not just theoretical but are based on practical experience. I thank the minister for his assurances and his commitment—and I accept them.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the international publicity that incident received I want to make a couple of comments. PARA.TAB: The case is being reviewed independently by the Ombudsman. I was very keen for that to happen; and I am still waiting on the report from the Ombudsman. The Ombudsman has been provided with all information relevant to the case. When the Ombudsman makes a report to parliament, that will be available to senators.

I assure you that we are very sensitive about having incidents like that treated very carefully. We understand that the international publicity could be quite damaging. But so far I have seen no evidence that customs staff involved have gone through other than correct procedures. One thing I am aware of is that, when the woman was being questioned, there was direct contact between customs staff at the barrier at the airport and senior staff in Canberra, with officers asking advice about what the next step should be in the way they handled this case. This amendment is a partial method of addressing this. I also understand that some Aboriginal and other communities may operate their power stations in a way that charges people for units of power used. This would be commercial under the current definition of `residential rebate'.

According to non-government organisations which have spoken to us, some remote communities do not get a rebate and so use fuel oil in an attempt to reduce costs. Government has verified this and has estimated that 21 per cent, or 110 millilitres, of light fuel oil is used for power generation. Industry sources believe this is an underestimate.
