TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes Greens amendment No. 7. We oppose it because it would uphold the recent AAT decision—what is called the Cowell Electric decision. The Greens amendment, if it were carried out, would substantially extend the provisions of the diesel fuel rebate scheme way beyond what it was envisaged for. Senator Margetts, you are trying to extend the scheme, which may be what you want to do, but I think that senators should understand that, were your amendment to succeed, existing electricity companies, state authorities, which run diesel generating operations in remote areas as part of their activities would get a rebate.

PARA.TAB: For various obvious reasons, state governments have often directed those authorities to pay a subsidy because of the disadvantage of those mainly remote areas—they have subsidised the provision of that electricity. I will tell you what would happen: they would then take the rebate and reduce their subsidy. In effect, you are proposing to the federal government that we take on the subsidisation of what the states are already doing as part of their program.

If that is what you want, that is fine, but let us make sure that you and the Senate understand that we would then be setting up a system whereby effectively we would be taking over the subsidisation provided by state electricity authorities by providing the diesel fuel rebate for the generation of electricity in these remote and rural towns.

Senator, I can think of half a dozen places in my own state where rebate under your amendment would be paid. There are many in North Queensland, in Western Australia and in New South Wales. I have not got a comprehensive list across the board because no-one has ever drawn up the list, but my knowledge and experience with this scheme leads me to believe that the list will turn out much bigger than you or I would envisage. We would then find state electricity generating authorities starting to make real arrangements by saying, `This is a free kick for us. We will actually switch to using more diesel generation because we will get the rebate, and that will be cheaper than other forms of generation of electricity.'

I am not sure that we should make distorted decisions about electrical generation by diesel fuel vis-a-vis any other fuel. That is what the impact of your decision would be. This is very hard for us to estimate, and I do not want to overestimate or underestimate it. My officers, since Senator Margetts has suggested this amendment, have tried to work out what they think the cost would be. Their estimate now is that approximately $35 million extra would be going into the scheme. This is an outlay over and above the existing scheme.

It may be Senator Margetts' view that that is an excellent thing to do but, if we want to subsidise or help remote towns, then quite frankly that is a different debate regarding general regional development issues. This scheme was never designed to provide assistance for electrical generation to all of the remote towns of Australia. Senator Margetts may say that that is a very good idea and I may not disagree with her if she is dealing with a particular allocation that might go through under regional development but, to keep extending the diesel fuel rebate scheme in the way that she is proposing will, in the end, destroy the rationale and the scheme itself. From the very beginning the rationale for the scheme, overwhelmingly, was that it was to be directly associated with agriculture, mining, fisheries and forestry. Senator Margetts is suggesting that remote towns, no matter what they use the power for, should have access to the rebate—that is the impact of her amendment. That will increase the outlays by $35 million.

I say to the opposition and to the Democrats that, if they are consistent about saying that government expenditure must be reduced and outlays must be brought down, they cannot support the Greens' amendment because this will increase outlays by at least $35 million. We are not talking about $1 or $2 million here; we are talking about at least $35 million. I suspect that that is an underestimate because in the past, whenever one thought a small change was being made by a court decision, it has ended up being used to crowbar out the whole wall so that a bus could drive through and collect all the money.

So I think the Greens' amendment will extend the scheme much more than is envisaged. I do not think this should be done because in the end it will destroy the scheme. That may be Senator Margetts' long-term objective; I do not know. It is not the government's objective; we want this scheme to be directed at agriculture, mining, fisheries and forestry in accordance with the existing rules. We are clarifying them; this will extend them, so we strongly object to this amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —We often wonder exactly what it was that this particular scheme was meant to achieve. It seems to have been cobbled together. It also occurs to me that the mess we are trying to deal with in the Customs and Excise Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 and the Customs, Excise and Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill 1995 may well be related to the fact that we were still hearing until just before the budget that there was the possibility that the mining diesel rebate would be adjusted downwards. Maybe we should have had some clear rationale. It seems that the government has tried to cobble together various cuts and to charge various people extra amounts of money to scrape up the extra revenue.
—But you are extending the revenue; you are extending the other way.

—Exactly. Whilst you are trying to get money grabs from various areas to add to your revenue we are trying to ask how people will be affected. We are also looking at this in conjunction with such things as the light fuel oil package, trying to find out how we as a parliament or as a Senate can get together a package which will actually look at the impact on people. I know that this is not dollars, but it is about people and about the impact on communities.

PARA.TAB: If, for instance, the Commonwealth government says that our role is to look at the impact of diesel fuel and to charge customs—and in general terms in recent years the federal government has been cutting back in a number of areas regarding assistance to the states—and if that means there might be some areas where the states benefit, then perhaps that is not such a bad thing. I do not think that it is necessarily a negative thing. It might mean the states have some money for things like education. Gee, that would be terrible!

We are trying to find out who you are impacting on and how you can mitigate the scheme so that it actually benefits the people who need it—instead of just saying, `Where are we going to get the money?' and only seeing it in terms of dollars. Give us the rationale or show us how it can be sorted out in a way that is fairer. We have asked for that but we have not seen too much evidence of it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak to this amendment. We will not be supporting this particular amendment. We believe it is a major extension of the scheme beyond the intent expressed in 1982 and beyond the intent expressed even before that. That is not arguing against some consideration being given to this particular proposition, but this is not the correct place in which to deal with it. It is not the correct legislation. It should be dealt with on its merits. If you were going to be dealing with this particular amendment in this legislation you would have to introduce into the bill, I believe, a totally new category which does not exist currently in the legislation. With those comments I announce that we will not be supporting the amendment. However, we would be sympathetic to the Greens if they brought forward a proposal which addressed this particular issue. We could deal with it on its merits at that time.

—The Australian Democrats are sympathetic to the thrust of the amendment; in fact, we considered a similar one at one stage. I believe the situation is that, while there is merit in this particular amendment, it needs to be looked at in the context of the forthcoming review and overall reassessment of the thrust of these provisions in the government's fuel excise rebate policy.

PARA.TAB: The policy directions are not at all clear. People living in remote areas are not often considered in government legislation. We would be supportive of this particular concession being extended to them. We would like to have cleared up what happens in the Commonwealth-state relationship and the extent to which there would be a transfer from Commonwealth funds to state revenue. That is a fairly heavy question that needs to be resolved. The actual expenditure of up to $35 million in the current budget concerns us, but in the overall policy direction of this particular legislation the government should seriously consider the benefit to people in remote areas.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the minister was a bit over-concerned in relation to the open-ended nature of this amendment. It only extends to heat and power, and these are uses that are already applicable under the residential rebate. Statements like `if it is open ended, everyone will use it and it will go forever' do not equate to reality.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government will accept opposition amendment No. 4 and amendment No. 5. We accept them because they relate to what we accepted with the Australian Democrats amendment on residential. This is one reason why we wanted to go through the legislation in this order. As you bring up the individual amendments in these categories we can deal with them in this way. I am doing this to save time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4)Schedule 1, page 5, item 2, omit the item.
(5)Schedule 1, page 5, item 3, omit the item.
As the minister said, these proposed amendments are consequential to previous amendments we have passed.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens will be supporting those opposition amendments.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (20)Schedule 1, page 5, item 4, definition of "agriculture", paragraph (g), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraphs:

TAB.TAB: "(g)the transporting of live-stock to an agricultural property:

PARA.TAB: (i)for the purpose of rearing; or
(ii)for the purpose of agistment; or

(ga)the return journey from a place referred to in paragraph (g) of the vehicles or equipment used in transporting the livestock, if that journey is for the purpose of later carrying out the transportation referred to in paragraph (g) or for the backloading of raw materials or consumables for use in a core agricultural activity; or
(gb)the transport of raw materials, consumables and equipment used in a core agricultural activity to the agricultural property; or".

SPEECH.PARA: The first point I want to make about this amendment is that it relates to the off-road component of the backloading operation. It is part of a practice that has been in existence for many years in agriculture so it is not an extension of the current scheme. It existed before 1982 and has existed since. It has been a component of the claims agricultural people make for the diesel fuel rebate, particularly in pastoral areas where there are many private roads and many kilometres covered. It is important as an efficiency measure and environmentally because one truck, one operation, does the job.

PARA.TAB: I think it would be absolutely crazy for the government to knock off or defeat this amendment because it would interfere very greatly with that arrangement. It would create a situation where pastoralists, in particular, but farmers in general, would be forced to make a decision so they could protect their diesel fuel rebate for the outward journey. They would get another operator to operate in the other direction.

With those comments—obviously if the debate develops on this, we will pursue it—I will close by saying that as far as customs advice in mining is concerned, it has already been established. I wish to comment on the fact that lime is backloaded for the beneficiation process at a beneficiation plant. It is well and truly customary for all trucks to cart fuel back to the mine when they return from the beneficiation operation. When they go into remote areas and there is a strip, they put avgas on the back of a truck and cart it back without jeopardising their position with the diesel fuel rebate off public roads or on private roads.
I commend this addition to the so-called sweeper clauses and hope that the government, the Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine support us.

TALK.START.PARA: —On balance, the Greens are inclined to support this amendment because it is a bit silly to subsidise empty trucks. We do not particularly want to encourage trucks rather than rail, but often this is not an option in these particular circumstances. To use Commonwealth money to subsidise empty trucks travelling around the country is not a particularly wise idea.
—The Australian Democrats will be supporting this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government opposes this amendment. I wish to make it quite clear that this is an extension of the scheme. When we had discussions through the Senate Economics Legislation Committee and the estimates committee with Senator Crane we openly accepted many of his suggestions for the sweeper clauses and the definitions so long as they did not extend the scheme. Government amendment no. (1), which has already been carried, states, in part:

SPEECH.PARA: the transporting of live-stock to an agricultural property;

PARA.TAB: (i)for the purpose of rearing; or
(ii)for the purpose of agistment; or

SPEECH.PARA: the mustering of live-stock undertaken:

PARA.TAB: (i)by a person who carries on a core agricultural activity; or
(ii)by a person contracted by that person to carry out the mustering;

SPEECH.PARA: on the agricultural property where the core agricultural activity is carried on.

During a discussion in the Economics Legislation Committee we accepted that that was a reasonable case. The opposition is now adding to that definition that anybody taking a product to or from the property can claim the rebate.

PARA.TAB: I want to point out to Senator Crane that this is one of the few times that the court has shown common sense. On two occasions when what Senator Crane is now outlining was appealed, the Federal Court ruled that it was not eligible; firstly, in August 1985 in relation to the Australian National Railways Commission's carting of fertilisers; and, secondly, in July 1993 in relation to the cartage of stock feed. In our view, the track record of this scheme shows that the court has always been far too lenient in extending the scheme. On two occasions when it has been appealed, the court has upheld the government's position that what Senator Crane is now moving is not eligible.

We are quite clearly extending the scheme. I want to emphasise again that it has never been the intention in the clarification and design of this legislation that we should extend the scheme. We want to make sure that those who were eligible continue to get it. Quite clearly, the court has ruled in our favour twice. The opposition is now extending it.

I do not know yet whether there is an estimate of what this would cost—it is very hard to cost this—but it will obviously run into millions of dollars. When you start allowing any truck that is delivering product to a big property, once it moves off the road and starts claiming that proportion to the diesel—Mayne Nickless or any major trucking company will start claiming—the costs will be considerable; it will run into millions of dollars.

Although the committee has sympathy for what seems like a reasonable area to extend it to—costs borne by outback farmers with big farms in big rural areas in particular, where there are transport costs—you are proposing to extend the scheme. I urge the committee to reject Senator Crane's amendment. I hope that both Senator Spindler and Senator Margetts—now that I have explained that this is an extension of the scheme twice rejected by the court—can review their position and vote against Senator Crane's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister, you have mentioned the decision of the court, but this will not affect retrospective decisions, will it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, it will not. It will not affect the retrospectivity because, clearly, we have won the court case, and we have had our position upheld. The issue of retrospectivity, which we are still to come to, is not at issue here, because we do not want to retrospectively expand the scheme.

—I have to take issue with some of the things the minister said. To begin with, the two cases that he raised are not applicable, nor are they relevant in terms of this amendment we are putting forward. I would re-emphasise very strongly that this is custom and practice which has occurred in agricultural and pastoral pursuits. The cases that the minister raised related to the railways. We make it quite clear in amendment No. 20. Subparagraph (gb) of this amendment says `to the agricultural property'. No train goes to an agricultural property. We also make the point in this amendment—and we are very careful with the wording—about raw materials or consumables: once again, transported to the property for use in the core agricultural activity. It is not an extension. You cannot carry it back and cart it to your neighbour.

PARA.TAB: Minister, you just misrepresented absolutely and totally what is in this particular amendment and what occurs in the operation, whether it be in pastoral areas or agricultural areas. There was to be a major benefit in clarifying this—and you said many times that we had to clarify and do these one by one. Our preferred position was to tighten up the real sweeper clause—the other operations clause that was there. Nonetheless, we have accepted the government's position to tighten some of these things up.

TALK.START.PARA: —Let's have it so that we can deal with them the way we are—one by one.

—We have accepted that this legislation should reflect what has been happening out there in the real world. We have worded this amendment, as I said, very carefully so that it cannot be abused, so it does not qualify you to cart it back to your neighbour.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen The Hon C.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I can save some time if I can just make a comment here. The real issue for us is subparagraph (gb) of your amendment. That is a wide open provision containing a new extension. We would accept subparagraph (ga) of your amendment because we think that does not extend the scheme. Subparagraph (gb) does. It states:

PARA.TAB: the transport of raw materials, consumables and equipment used in a core agricultural activity to the agricultural property . . .

SPEECH.PARA: We believe that really is opening up a whole new area that will cost us revenue or outlays. We are willing to say, on balance and with goodwill, that we think we can sustain subparagraph (ga) without blowing out the outlays but covering some of the points you have covered and we have discussed previously when dealing with issues about mustering and so on at the Senate legislation committee. I want to make an offer to you: if you drop off subparagraph (gb), we will support subparagraph (ga). But we will not support (gb) under any circumstance.

TALK.START.PARA: —As we have said before, this is an opportunity to look at some of the anomalies in the legislation. We have looked very carefully at this amendment. We certainly support subsections (g) and (ga). Would Senator Crane consider deleting subsection (gb), because there appears to be some value in the minister's argument on it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —A bird in the hand is better than two in the bush. We will accept that position and pursue the other amendment at a different time. Nonetheless, I want to make it absolutely clear that we do not accept the proposition that was put to us that subsection (gb) is an extension to the scheme. Whether or not it is, it is a functional operation that has been carried on for many years in agriculture as part of the process and it has been claimed for many years by many producers or their contractors. The other point we must make in terms of defining these clauses is that we cannot be at a standstill as far as defining and clarifying what is eligible and what one might take out. But, having rejected your argument, I will withdraw my original amendment and now move:

SPEECH.PARA: (20)Schedule 1, page 5, item 4, definition of "agriculture", paragraph (g), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraphs:

TAB.TAB: "(g)the transporting of live-stock to an agricultural property:

PARA.TAB: (i)for the purpose of rearing; or
(ii)for the purpose of agistment; or

(ga)the return journey from a place referred to in paragraph (g) of the vehicles or equipment used in transporting the livestock, if that journey is for the purpose of later carrying out the transportation referred to in paragraph (g) or for the backloading of raw materials or consumables for use in a core agricultural activity; or
Amendment agreed to.
Amendment (by Senator Crane) proposed:

SPEECH.PARA: (21)Schedule 1, page 6, item 4, definition of "agriculture", paragraph (j), omit "an", substitute "any".

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —We accept the amendment. I have just been advised that it substitutes `any' for `an'.
—The Greens will also support the amendment as it relates to the realities of landcare, not just a very tight technical definition of what is applicable.

PARA.TAB: Amendment agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7)Schedule 1, page 6, item 4, definition of "agriculture", after paragraph (j), insert the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(jh)any activity undertaken for the purpose of soil or water conservation:

TAB.TAB: (i)by a person who carries on a core agricultural activity within an approved catchment area; or
(ii)by a person contracted by that person to carry out the first mentioned activity;

SPEECH.PARA: within the approved catchment area; or".

This is a matter we raised with the government in our discussions. It concerns the extension of the scheme. I accept that it is an extension of the scheme in one sense: in terms of definitions. But I certainly do not accept it as being an extension of the scheme with regard to practice and custom. We cannot include this as an amendment in terms of going back to 1982, although the fundamental landcare scheme did start in Western Australia in about 1981. It was certainly not part of the intent at that time.

PARA.TAB: As far as landcare is concerned, the development of approved farm plans running into approved catchment plans will mean that, in practice, anything up to 15, 20 or 30 properties will determine a course of action starting at a particular part of a valley, the side of a hill or wherever it might be on that particular plan and will work through it as a voluntary group.

Many of these plans involve a 20-year program. The individuals involved will take their machinery—bulldozer, plough, tractor or whatever—to wherever the plan is and work through it year by year or month by month planting trees, drainage or a number of similar activities to practically address soil conservation, water conservation, salinity control, wind erosion and a host of other things.

This is a legitimate aspect in the context of what has been put before us. I urge the government to reconsider its opposition to this amendment as such opposition would fly in the face of their landcare program. It would also fly in the face of the people involved at a state level—the departments of agriculture and the state governments.

The amendment includes work done on public land whether it be rivers, creeks or roadways. One of the realities of addressing soil degradation and the other environmental problems caused by erosion is that these problems do not begin or stop at the boundary of a farm, a leasehold or whatever. So I commend the amendment to the committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats strongly support this particular amendment. Clearly, soil and water conservation should be included in the rebate provisions on a practical basis. Many agricultural enterprises combine common activities in an approved catchment system. It would be totally counterproductive and bureaucratic to say the particular activity can only be subject to a rebate if it is carried out on the particular land belonging to that particular farmer.

PARA.TAB: The Australian Democrats believe that it is a sensible arrangement. While it does extend the scheme, it does so in a way which will pay dividends. The Democrats support it.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Greens (WA) also strongly support this amendment. It should become obvious to everyone and, hopefully, the government eventually, that you cannot stop catchment plans at the farm gate and that such plans would never be successful if you did stop them at the farm gate.

PARA.TAB: Forested and industrial areas cannot be excluded from a practical scheme. If a catchment area covers farming and residential areas, residential activity affects farm water and farm activities affect residential water. Until government policies look at this as a catchment system, we will continue to lack real directions in moving towards an answer in this area.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government cannot support this amendment. I think Senator Spindler has already acknowledged that this is a clear extension of the scheme. It is very difficult for us to estimate the extra cost in the outlays, because we are moving into an area that is almost impossible to measure.

PARA.TAB: The definition would allow any so-called `activity' in any declared catchment area—and the definition of catchment area would not be left up to us but to others. We estimate that a minimum of between $20 million and $30 million would be the annual cost to start off with. But my own suspicion is that once the smarties work out this particular amendment and the fact that the definition is so broad as a result of the consultants' work, that cost of $20 million to $30 million would rapidly rise.

Therefore, consistent with our position, I re-emphasise—even to the sake of boring the chamber—this fact: the bill was never designed to change the policy intent of the scheme. This amendment clearly changes the policy intent of the scheme. This is not an argument about the environment and so on. We all support improving the environment.
In the discussion on a previous clause, Senator Crane said that there are legitimate issues on transport that we may look at at another time and in another place in another policy development.

TALK.START.PARA: —Where?

—There are plenty of opportunities. Never let it be said that I wish to put more work on a Senate standing committee but, clearly, if you are concerned about these issues you could start the process by creating a reference for a standing committee to look at environmental activity associated with agriculture—land degradation and so on—and the best way to pay for and encourage that improvement to occur. Providing the diesel fuel rebate may not be the most effective use of the dollars involved. With the $20 million or $30 million, we may be able to achieve a much more effective outcome for the environment than by providing cheap diesel. That is the issue. You asked how we would do it. This is an area that a standing committee may choose to have a reference on and investigate.

PARA.TAB: In the committee hearings on this legislation, as a result of Senator Crane's suggestion and the discussion, we agreed to an amendment dealing with soil and water conservation. That is in the amendments. That is clearly defined. You are proposing a much broader amendment than that covering soil and water conservation. The definition is open to the widest possible interpretation. I know the scheme will be abused, in a sense, by people climbing in and finding reasons to claim they are doing environmental work.

The next issue is the catchment area. You could end up with a definition that the whole of Australia is a catchment area. Is the Murray-Darling basin, under the legislation establishing the Murray-Darling Commission, a catchment area? In that area are agricultural land, Crown land and national parks automatically eligible for rebate for any activity by a Commonwealth authority or a state authority such as the department of wildlife or the department of conservation? As I read this amendment, they would be eligible for the diesel fuel rebate.

We are again getting into this issue that we are subsidising state governments. We are giving them the free kick. Arrangements about who pays for what should be done directly by negotiations, on a bilateral basis, rather than by accidentally handing it over by an amendment that is so wide in its application.

We have bent over backwards to accommodate Senator Crane's legitimate concerns that anybody legitimately involved in agriculture, mining, fisheries or forestry can continue to get the rebate. We have even improved the definition of soil and water conservation so that it is directly related to agricultural production and a person's property. As a result of Senator Crane's suggestion, we have extended that to the adjoining property so long as it is an agricultural farm if it is in the same water catchment area. You want to extend this definition of a water catchment area to the whole of Australia.

The problems are: who approves the water catchment area? We are in the hands of the state governments. You and I know what will happen if we hand this over to the state governments. They will work out a way they can claim the diesel fuel rebate for all activities by their departments of environment, land, conservation and agriculture. The New South Wales government will declare the whole state a water catchment area for this purpose and will get the rebate. I am certain this was never the intent of the scheme.

I have just been given a note by my advisers. As far as they are aware, under state legislation everywhere is a catchment area. You have not defined how we determine a catchment area. You have not even left it to us to determine a catchment area; you have left it to somebody else. I do not think the federal budget ought to be left open to someone else to make these interpretations in an uncapped, open-ended way. If the Senate is concerned about expenditure outlays, it must reject this amendment.

We have already accepted constructive suggestions from Senator Crane in the committee stage. We have included them because they are not extending the scheme. It is actually been defined and properly dealt with. So, on this issue, Senator Crane, we will strongly oppose the amendment. I will have to call a division because your amendment would actually substantially increase outlays.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not going to spend a lot of time, for no other reason than that I am frightened of my whip. There are a couple of points that I must answer. I am sorry, Minister, that you have chosen to misrepresent the situation. I am also sorry that you are not aware that there is a standing committee already looking at the whole landcare program. The point I want to make is that it has to be within an approved catchment area, and within an approved catchment area you have to have a catchment plan.

PARA.TAB: These are procedures that the federal government has agreed to with the states. You said that that would make state governments eligible for the scheme. That is nonsense. Rather, it absolutely restricts it to the person who carries on the activity. That is just not a reasonable proposition. I am not going to sit here and argue with you all day because you will continue to misrepresent the facts of how the landcare program works, how catchment areas are set up. I think you confused LCGs with catchment areas in your comments. I might be able to give you a briefing on how the whole system works and what actually happens in the real world when we finish this bill.

TALK.START.PARA: —The reality is as Senator Crane suggests. It is one of the responsibilities of the landcare groups to look not only at their own properties but also at what feeds into their properties. It is unlikely that they will be carrying on specific landcare areas activities right down to catchment areas such as the Murray-Darling basin. If there were areas where there were specific government enticements and encouragement for people to be involved specifically in landcare activities in catchments, then maybe we would not have the revolting mess that we have in the Murray-Darling basin. I do not know how much money we have thrown at it already without actually doing something about the problem.

PARA.TAB: We are talking about the people who are actually doing something, not the people who are thinking about doing something. We are talking about not penalising the people who are doing things, not necessarily for their own financial benefit, but landcare groups who are actually recognising that areas outside their specific properties are necessary for their work to have impact. It would be a jolly good thing if people took this up.

If we are going to talk about relative values, the Greens believe that if we are going to have a diesel fuel rebate for the whole of the mining industry, our preference would be for more encouragement specifically for these activities. In the end, they will save money. If we do not look at integrating these values into our other areas, someone is going to have to pay. It will be the community, the environment and the farmers. It will be to the detriment of people downstream in residential areas who end up with a smelly, putrid, dead mess of a river.
The reality is that money is not saved. We might save a few dollars in the short term. In the end, this is much more wise than having piecemeal solutions and trying to fix the problems later.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Crane mentioned a person who carries on a core agricultural activity. In the second paragraph it says `by a person contracted by that person to carry out that activity'. He may well be right. At the moment, he cannot see how a state government department or somebody else can latch on to this.

PARA.TAB: I have never underestimated the ingenuity of tax consultants, advisers and particularly state governments to find a way to use any method to try to latch on to federal outlays and revenues. That is why I take a very pessimistic view, not an optimistic one, about human nature in this case. The whole history of the scheme is that we ought to take a pessimistic view of the way that people spend all their energy trying to find out ways to extend it.

Senator Crane openly admitted that this proposal does extend the scheme. That is utterly unacceptable to the government. Everybody, particularly the opposition, screamed at us prior to the budget to reduce outlays. They said that we were increasing outlays by at least $20 to $30 million.

The argument about environmental policy is fine, but this program was never designed for that. Senator Margetts can take those issues on in another place or another committee and in another area of policy development. I warn the opposition again: if it keeps allowing this scheme to be extended, in the end the scheme will go. No-one will justify having a scheme that has open-ended attractions for people to come and dip into substantial taxpayers money. At the moment, it is running at around $1,200 million per annum and is going up by about $100 million per year.
Senator Margetts has suggested that we should knock off the mining industry and get it out of it. That is a major change to the scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —She likes the export income of them, though.
—Senator Panizza realises that this scheme is designed for the off-road costs of particular industries with an export orientation. That is how it was designed and how it should be left.

PARA.TAB: In other amendments, we have allowed it to apply to farmers and agricultural people where they have a specific conservation issue about water and soil care and so on on their property. We also allow it to apply to an adjacent property which affects them. But this is far too open. It is unacceptable. We do not want to waste time, but I will ask to call a division.

TALK.START.PARA: —I find the claims of the minister somewhat outlandish. We are talking about soil and conservation measures being undertaken by farmers on their land. I find it difficult to see how the minister can compute a figure of $20 to $30 million out of that. I would like the minister to provide some detail as to how he has arrived at that figure.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not just on agricultural land. The definition of catchment area also means off agricultural land. That is our point. That is why the definition has gone too broad. That is why it is now wide open. A lot of other people who he or I would never have thought eligible for it will now be able to move in and make it so. That may be good for policy issues somewhere else, but not for the diesel fuel rebate scheme.

PARA.TAB: Finally, why do we favour the consumption of diesel to enhance the environment? Perhaps we should be enhancing the consumption of petrol, LPG or whatever. Senator Spindler is saying, `We will say that forever and a day diesel fuel is the one that we will use to protect the inactivity and which allows an advantage over other fuels'. I do not think the Greens or the Democrats would ever agree that diesel is the best fuel or the best way to go. But that is the way they are attacking this. That is not the best way to proceed. They have allowed a definition that is broader than just the actual agricultural land.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the last few days we have debated competition policy and have been told, `No, this is not the place for the environment.' We have debated local government legislation and have been told, `No, this is not the place for the environment.' We have a piece of legislation dealing with agricultural activities and land care and Minister Schacht says, `No, this is not the place for the environment either.' I presume the minister means the place for the environment is the environment committee. I note that the government and the opposition do not take a lot of notice of the issues that environment committees tend to come up with. They say that is not about the real things in life; that it should be about the economy.

PARA.TAB: I point out that in EPAC surveys people in Australia say that government should be spending more money on the environment. They expect that the decision makers in this land will be prepared to integrate environment policy at all levels. The Greens and the Democrats are not suggesting that diesel is a preferred fuel, but if another piece of legislation comes up about another aspect of land care we will be in there batting for that aspect as well. We are told that it is not here and it is not there. Where do we find where the government is integrating sound environmental policy into its policies? If it is anything to do with the economy, local government or competition policy, the answer is no.

Here we have something specific, and it is not here either. It does not say much for the government's current understanding of where the general public is and what it is expecting to see from decision makers about understanding what is important and understanding what the costs will be in the future if we do not start integrating these policies into all areas of decision making.

TALK.START.PARA: —Minister Schacht suggested that it is open to everyone carrying out work within the approved catchment area to claim this rebate. The amendment is very clearly limited to any activity that is undertaken by a person who carries on a core agricultural activity within an approved catchment area. I believe that is a reasonable limit.

—Minister Schacht stood up here and asked `Why diesel?' If he is going to adopt that stance with a particular clause, he will have to adopt that for the whole bill. He cannot selectively choose. This amendment is extending customary practice out of what has grown from government policy, supported by all parties in this place, and the policy of state governments. It is restricted, as has been said.

PARA.TAB: Senator Margetts had a little shot at the opposition and the government. I do not think addressing the environment over the last 10 years in this parliament or in state parliaments has been the province of any party. I think everybody has made a contribution to the debate. The community at large has picked it up and is making a contribution. I do not think such comments help the debate. It is perfectly legitimate to put it in here, and I acknowledged at the start of the debate that it is an extension of the scheme. It has grown from government policy since 1982 and, as such, I support it very strongly.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Crane's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (5)Schedule 1, page 7, after item 4, insert the following item:

PARA.EMPHASIS: "4A. Subsection 164(7) (after paragraph (j) of the definition of `agriculture'):

SPEECH.PARA: Insert the following word and paragraph:
'or (ji) the carrying out of firefighting activities:

TAB.TAB: (i)by a person who carries on a core agricultural activity; or
(ii)by a person contracted by that person to carry out the first-mentioned activity;

SPEECH.PARA: on the agricultural property where the core agricultural activity is carried on or at a place adjoining, or in the proximity of, that place; or".

The amendment provides that the carrying out of firefighting activities should be included in the definition of agriculture. I think the argument is fairly self-evident. It is limited to a person who carries on a core agricultural activity on the agricultural property where the core activity is carried out or at a place adjoining or in the proximity of that place. Very clearly, one cannot determine the way a fire rushes through a particular area, and to try to limit it any more tightly would defeat the purpose of this particular amendment. I commend it to the Senate.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —We are willing to accept the Democrat amendment. However, we will accept it if the Democrats will agree to delete the words in the second line where it says `adjoining, or in the proximity of', and replace that with the words `adjacent to'. The reason is that `adjacent to' is the phrase that we have used all the way through the bill and we want consistency. We believe it does not affect the intent of the amendment; we do not believe it changes the scope of the scheme. If that is accepted we can then get on with a reasonable outcome.
—I would like to ask the minister whether he can give me an assurance that `adjacent to' encompasses `adjoining, or in the proximity of'.
—Yes.
—In that case, I am happy to accept that amendment accordingly.

—I would like some clarification. Later on in a couple of areas we have similar amendments because of the concern about the word `adjacent'. One area where we have brought it in pertains to firebreaks.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of the pressure of time, if Senator Crane is willing to insert `adjacent to' in lieu of the words he has, `proximity of', we would be willing to accept those amendments if he can make that adjustment.

—I think Senator Schacht has missed the point. The reason we put `adjoining, or in the proximity of' in regard to firebreaks is because once again in practice, if there is a fire in a national park and the captain commandeers 20 farmers with their ploughs and tractors to operate there for a week, there is no way that we can have `adjacent to'. We need a clear definition of what is meant by `adjacent to'. The dictionary says that `adjacent to' is `contiguous' or `near'. There is a whole range of things. There is a classic example I can give—

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will give you the definition to save time. In a court case `adjacent' was defined as `lying near, close or contiguous; adjoining; neighbouring'. That is the definition that we now have. I think the way you have described the situation of firebreaks in a national park and so on meets `adjacent to' under that definition that has now been established in a court case. I think that meets your concerns.
—Could you read that again?

—Yes. To put it on the record, it is Leslie Salt (A Department of Cargill Aust Ltd) v Collector of Customs. It is called `the Leslie Salt case'. The definition reads, `lying near, close or contiguous; adjoining; neighbouring'. If you have a national park next to, nearby or neighbouring the farm I cannot see how you can miss.
—It could be 20 miles away.

—You do not put that definition in. We have never put definitions in kilometres because if it is 21 kilometres away you might miss out. In those definitions it is generally `neighbouring'. I think we ought to stick to those definitions. Certainly, the government is keen to do that. We know now what we are dealing with.

—I will give a classic example. Take the case of a fire captain who commandeers or orders X number of farmers or bulldozer operators, or whoever it might be, to go on to a national park—as they did in the Fitzgerald fire a couple of years ago where one million acres were burnt. Some of them were there for three weeks with their machinery putting in fire breaks. Are you prepared to agree that that kind of activity is included in the definition? That is all I am worried about.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am advised yes, so long as it is the nearest park; not a park in another state. That is how we understand it and that is how we believe it operates. That is why we want to stick with this definition.

PARA.TAB: Amendment, as amended, agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (6)Schedule 1, page 6, item 4, definition of "agriculture", proposed paragraph (q), omit the paragraph, substitute the following paragraph:

PARA.TAB: "(q)an activity referred to in any one of paragraphs (a) to (d) unless the activity is carried out for the purposes of, or for purposes that will directly benefit, the following:
(i)a business undertaken to obtain produce for sale;
(ii)research conducted in a public research facility for the general benefit of commercial agriculture;".

SPEECH.PARA: This amendment relates to the definition of agriculture. Under the proposed definition only diesel used in a business undertaken to obtain produce for sale or to directly benefit such a business is eligible. We believe it excludes a small but very important class of activity which provides substantial indirect benefits for agriculture and which is only done in the interests of agriculture. This category is that of public research institutions including departments of agriculture and universities. The amendment would allow them to claim for what are, in all ways, equivalent to agricultural activities but not performed to obtain produce for sale. It would cover field trials, field stations and so on. We think these are legitimate operations so strongly connected to agriculture and of such direct and substantial benefit to agriculture that they must be included in the definition of rebatable activities.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose the amendment. It would mean that a whole range of government public sector state and federal activities that have never ever been considered as eligible for diesel fuel rebate would actually get it. For example, CSIRO would then be eligible to claim their diesel fuel rebate. I have to say that that is really switching one bit of government money into another pocket and vice versa. There is a whole range of other institutions. It is not the original intent of the scheme. It is extending the scheme—and you know my arguments about that. Therefore we oppose the amendment.
—If CSIRO is already paying the diesel fuel levy—
—They are paying the normal excise.

—Then money is already going from one government area to another. We must recognise that this is not interminable. There are specific research categories with CSIRO's agriculture activities that relate to the diesel fuel rebate. There are specific and limited areas in which the universities are also involved in these activities. Most universities have specific activities. We are not opening the floodgates. If anything, in recent times, there has been a pulling back of CSIRO's activities in rural research. Money is already going from one public purse into another. It seems an anomaly that these activities are excised out of the excise rebate. There does not seem to be any logic to it.
—I wonder if either Senator Margetts or the minister could advise the Senate of the magnitude of expenditure concerned?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —Obviously, looking at the size of these institutions, it will cost some millions of dollars. I could not say whether it would be $5 million or $20 million but when you encourage these public institutions to use diesel because of the rebate, you will get a big increase in expenditure. It will run into millions of dollars.

—The opposition will not be supporting this amendment. We believe that it is an extension of the scheme. We recognise that these organisations—agricultural departments, the CSIRO, and so on—are already in receipt of extensive contributions from the public purse. They could not operate without those contributions. We believe that, in addressing their particular needs, there are other forums in which to do that. We have had problems with aspects of that which are being dealt with presently.

PARA.TAB: If you are going to introduce a research category for the diesel fuel rebate you would have to define the area under which it came and thereby extend the scheme. That is something we might want to look at in the future but it is not appropriate in this context where we are dealing with core agricultural activities.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the absence of a very clear definition and assessment of the cost involved, and since this matter goes to a policy decision affecting the whole of the legislation, the Australian Democrats believe that the matter should be dealt with in the same way as the exemption for people living in remote areas. That is, it should come under the rubric of the review of the diesel fuel rebate and its policy objectives rather than being done on the run. The Democrats will not be supporting the amendment.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN (Senator Reynolds)—I have to ask you to go back on the running sheet to government amendment No. 6(jb), in relation to which the opposition has foreshadowed moving its amendment 22.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—We have dealt with this in principle, and we have the definition of `adjacent', so—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (22)Schedule 1, page 6, item 4, definition of "agriculture", proposed paragraph (jb), omit "adjoining", substitute "adjacent to".
(23)Schedule 1, page 6, item 4, definition of "agriculture", proposed paragraph (je), after "water troughs", insert ", water channels".

(24)Schedule 1, page 6, item 4, definition of "agriculture", proposed paragraph (je), after "drainage systems", insert "including, without limiting the generality of the foregoing, water pipes and water piping".

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The government accepts opposition amendment No. 22 because it has accepted the words `adjacent to' being inserted. We also accept amendment No.s 23 and 24.

PARA.TAB: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: 8.Schedule 1, page 7, omit item 7.

This amendment says that things such as sand, clay, granite or industrial minerals should remain in the definition. Unless this gets into a horrific debate, I will not go over it. Later I will table a document which supports our position that most, if not all, of these things have been recognised and under the previous scheme prior to 1982 were recognised as being included in this scheme. It is only in more recent years, from about 1987-88, that the refunding of the rebate to these producers was considered by customs not to be part of the definition.

PARA.TAB: If we are going to go into a long debate, I will go into a long debate and put my views across or the government can take that on face value. I have the information and the evidence here, which I am sure the department and the minister are well aware of. I leave my comments there at the moment. We believe that those minerals, et cetera, should be included in the definition. They were in the scheme to begin with and it was the intent that they be in the scheme. As I said earlier, it is very difficult to differentiate between the operations of clay in making house bricks and tiles, et cetera, as opposed to digging another mineral out of the ground and processing that into some product.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose the amendment. The impact of the opposition's amendment is to remove our definition of minerals—that is, excluding sand, sandstone, soil, slate, clay, other than Bentonite or Kaolin, basalt, gravel, granite, limestone or water. We think that this clearly defines what the minerals section was all about from the very beginning. If our position is not supported, the opposition is clearly extending the scheme into quarrying in a very big way. Privately, members in the minerals council are certainly apprehensive to have them lumped in with quarrying, which is nothing to do with minerals and the export industry at all. We believe that the opposition's amendment has to be rejected.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats will not be supporting the coalition's amendment. I would like to quote some words of Mr Justice Kitto in a 1955 case where he said that the two activities, quarrying and mining, can be very distinctly differentiated. He says:

SPEECH.PARA: It would, I think, be unusual to apply the word `mine' to open diggings for the obtaining of stone of a kind which does not call up, by association, the idea of mining in the sense of sinking a shift and tunnelling in pursuit of a desired substance.

We believe that mining has always had the interpretation of extracting minerals from the soil rather than dredging up sand, clay or other materials themselves. In fact, the original 1982 guideline issued for the rebate specifically excluded quarrying:
This definition of mining does not include quarrying operations carried on for the sole purpose of obtaining stone for building, road making or similar purposes.
Admittedly, that was muddied a little later when the rebate for sand mining was paid in the mid-1980s.

PARA.TAB: The quarrying industry, through KPMG, made a case to Customs in 1992 seeking `equitable' treatment with mining—their emphasis—but this was unambiguously refused by the department. That was a clear statement to the industry that it was not entitled to that rebate. There is a whole range of cases in which the courts have decided that quarrying is not mining: the New South Wales Associated Blue Metal Quarries case, the North Australian Cement case, the Sanders Quarries case and at least one of the Neumann dredging cases.

We believe it is difficult in this legislation, as I have said before, to find a rationale for when the rebate should be applied and which industries it should apply to. The legislation so far has concentrated on mining and agriculture. One of the justifications for picking out those two industries is that both of them are export industries, essentially and substantively, and that, for our economic well-being, we are intent as a nation to give every assistance we can in the global competitive environment to industries which do assist in this effort. It is difficult to see how one could equate quarrying with that particular purpose.

If quarrying were to be included on the basis that it does assist some industries—including road and house building—even in a very minimal way, I would want the rebate to be extended to manufacturing. High-tech manufacturing—an industry such as the car industry—we would want to have supported on the basis that it contributes a tremendous amount to our export effort and to our economic well-being. For all these reasons, the Australian Democrats do not feel disposed to support the coalition's amendment.

TALK.START.PARA: —This amendment would include quarrying specifically in the definition of mining. We oppose this. The Greens (WA) have always argued that the mining rebate is a subsidy and is too generous, and we will not support its extension unless there is some strong reason to do so. We openly support the idea that the mining rebate should be decreased and perhaps we would be able to give a bit more justice to some of the people who we are otherwise lopping off. We are happy to support any amendment to the effect of decreasing the mining rebate, but we will not be supporting the extension to quarrying in the definition.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3)Schedule 1, page 7, item 7, omit ", limestone or water", substitute " or limestone".
(4)Schedule 1, page 7, after item 7, insert the following item:
At the end, add:
`In this Act, water is not to be considered to be a mineral.'.".

The Greens' amendments Nos 3 and 4 specifically take `water' out of the definition of excluded quarrying activities. Amendment No. 4 creates a new item 7(a), which excludes water from the definition of minerals. Amendment No. 1 already stated that 7(a) applied since 1986.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator, your amendment is to take `water' out of the definition of quarrying. By the defeat of the opposition's amendment, `water' has already been taken out. I think your amendment is probably redundant. That is what I am advised—and I think that is right. I do not think you have to proceed because we have taken `water' out of item 7 of the bill.
—The reason we are moving our amendment is that we would like to make the point that water could be treated retrospectively as a clarification but quarrying could not.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —We will deal with the retrospectivity of the clause when we get the bill.

PARA.TAB: Amendments negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (3)Schedule 1, page 7, after item 7, insert the following item:
Omit ` "minerals" means minerals in any form', substitute ` "minerals" means minerals (other than uranium) in any form.'.".

This amendment requests the government to reduce the expenditure on the rebate by excluding uranium from the definition of minerals to be mined. As I said in my second reading speech, the diesel fuel rebate scheme is a scheme with no social objectives. It pays rebates willy-nilly to some groups, irrespective of the social value of what they do—we have had some discussions on that this morning—and pays a lower rebate to others, such as hospitals and aged care homes when there are few activities more socially valuable than the services of such facilities.

PARA.TAB: Others which are excluded—such as rail services, which are the lifeblood of our transportation network and marine tourist operators—are no less valuable as exporters than those in the farming, fishing, mining, and forestry industries or manufacturers which use diesel fuel for electricity generation. The diesel fuel rebate scheme does not reflect any of these priorities. The scheme needs to be fully reviewed so that the $1 billion or so paid in rebates can actually be directed, on an equitable basis, towards activities consistent with our national goals.

It is beyond the resources of the Democrats to fix all the policy anomalies of the scheme. We are not attempting to do that in every case, as I have indicated previously. However, since France decided a fortnight ago to resume nuclear testing at Mururoa Atoll, it seems to us that the government should accept the Democrats amendment to remove uranium from the rebate.

Not only are we mining uranium and selling it in a way which inevitably means some of it will finish up in French hands—and ultimately will be exploded at Mururoa Atoll—but we even support that by offering a rebate. Surely, that is madness. I commend the amendment to both the coalition and the government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —We oppose the amendment. We do not think one should differentiate between mining activities. The issue of uranium should be debated elsewhere—not in this bill. Those existing contracts to supply uranium to France were signed many years ago under our verification and international agreements. We do not accept that that uranium ends up in atomic bombs being tested at Mururoa. We oppose the amendment.
—It probably will not surprise anyone that the Greens will be supporting the Democrats amendment in this regard.
—The minister could consider that we have had evidence of flag swapping. Is he totally ignoring that evidence when he says that our uranium will not finish up in French hands?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —No, we are not ignoring it. The case is not proven at all—and it has been debated previously in this place.
—Surprise, surprise! We will not be supporting this either.

PARA.TAB: Amendment negatived.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Spindler asked me a question about the first bill we debated and an incident involving a Taiwanese lady. In view of the fact that this has attracted international attention, it is appropriate to put this brief comment on the record now.

PARA.TAB: When we were debating the Customs, Excise and Bounty Legislation Amendment Bill, Senator Spindler raised the search of a Taiwanese passenger by Customs at Sydney Airport. I am advised that the ombudsman wrote to the chief executive of Customs on 8 June. She found that the Customs officials acted appropriately under the Customs legislation and acted in a proper manner. I will have my office provide Senator Spindler and Senator Parer with a copy of her report.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek the assistance of the committee. I looked at the running sheet; I believe that we just ran out of context with the Greens' amendments 3 and 4—and I did not hear a response from the opposition. I looked through the running sheet to see where amendments 1, 2 and 5 were. Unless the government can advise me otherwise, those amendments are not there. You have pulled two amendments out of context and they have become meaningless. If they are somewhere else, will you please tell me. The reality is that those amendments need to be moved in bulk and you need to understand the necessity for the five amendments to be moved and the problems that may cause the government if we cannot move those amendments in bulk.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —My advice is that amendments 1, 2 and 5 are issues of commencement. We said before that we will deal with those at the end after we go through schedules 1 and 2. However, we want to have the commencement issue finalised.
—I am sorry, but they are not actually on the running sheet.

—The running sheet only went to the amendments dealing with the substance of the bill and not the issue of the commencement date. The amendments will be dealt with at the end of finalising the commencement date. I can assure you, Senator Margetts, that there is no intention to accidentally slip them off.

—I seek the indulgence of the committee. When I am allowed to deal with amendments 1, 2 and 5, can we recommit amendments 3 and 4 so that I have the opportunity to explain the connection between amendments 3 and 4 to 1, 2 and 5?

—Senator Margetts is correct about amendments 3 and 4: there was no response from myself. I took the minister at face value that because you did not support our previous amendment, there was nothing before us in the bill from which you could take them away because they had been taken away in the total context. That was my understanding. Is it correct that we had already moved them?

—Your amendment was to delete what we were putting in on the definition of minerals. We were excluding certain rocks and so on from the definition of minerals—and one of those was water. Your amendment was defeated—they were out—so water is out.
—That is my understanding—it is not there any more.

—Yes. Senator Margetts, when the new definition, as it now is, commences, that will be dealt with when we find out what we have put into the bill and what we have taken out. Quite appropriately, the commencement issue is at the end.
—If it is necessary for us to come back to this matter because there has been a misunderstanding, I will support Senator Margetts.
—If Senator Margetts feels that there has been a misunderstanding, by accident, we will cooperate. We must keep in consideration the time pressures we are operating under.

—I am trying to assist the government. Numbers 3 and 4 enable us to support that element of retrospectivity, because we believe it separates out the two. If the government does not want us to support retrospectivity, be it on your head. This will give you the chance to mull it over in between time.
—We understand that.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen A.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9)Schedule 1, page 7, item 8, definition of "mining operations", paragraph (a), after "prospecting", insert ", mine development".

This is a very simple amendment to the so-called sweeper clause in terms of definitions. We believe `mine development' should have been included. It may have come in under `prospecting'. Paragraph (a) in clause 8 in the schedule to the bill states that mining operations mean exploration, prospecting or mining for minerals. We believe it should include `mine development' as well because it is custom and practice as far as mining is concerned.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —You are seeking to insert `mine development'. We think that definition is too broad. We are not quite sure what it means. We understand, privately, you think it means mine shafts. That definition is too broad for us and would extend the scheme. If you could find a way of defining it better so that we know what we are dealing with and are not accidentally extending the scheme, we would have some sympathy. At the moment, `mine development' is too broad.

—I would have thought that was the most restrictive part of the proposition we have in front of us. You have `exploration'. You cannot get much broader or wider than `exploration'. You have `prospecting'. You cannot get much broader or wider than `prospecting'. The same applies with regard to `mining for minerals'. I might have to think about different words.

PARA.TAB: When we talk about mine development, we are talking about what happens after the time the approval has been given by the respective mines departments to mine and the mine can begin and progress. I said that a mine shaft would be an example. If it was an open-cut mine, it could well be the preparation of the area. It would certainly be confined to that period of time after approvals were given for the development of the mine until the actual mining operation took place. The `mine development' could well be taking the top soil off the area and putting it aside in the dump for use in the rehabilitation process. It is explicitly excluded at present. We are trying to get every word perfect. It is that process after approval has been given for the mine to start, to get it ready, so they can start mining. It fits between the exploration, the prospecting and the mining production.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have just been advised that, the way you have described it, it is already covered by the definition of mining. From the time they put the first shovel in the ground for preparation, that is already covered. You do not need this amendment.
—Could you point to where it is?
—The Federal Court has ruled already on this definition, and that is why it is covered. We are not changing it.

—I would like it included in the legislation. I can see no reason why this amendment should not be proceeded with. I was not aware of the court decision. The amendment absolutely clarifies the position in legislation.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —You would need a proper definition of `mine development'. From experience, we are worried that people have a clever way of defining things to mean something else. What you are raising is already covered and is eligible for the diesel fuel rebate, and it will be paid. We think your amendment is unnecessary.

—I simply ask you one question. You have given us an undertaking in Hansard that every bit of mine development is covered. Can you give me that assurance once more? Is there anything in mining development that you can think of that may be excluded? From the approval of mining right through the production process, is there anything in your view that can be excluded?

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The way it is being paid at the moment specifically for mine development, yes. The Federal Court has ruled that way. I will put it this way. Would construction of a railway be part of the mine development in the opposition's view? To specifically include mine development could open up a whole new area for interpretation. It is far too broad.

PARA.TAB: A railway line being built, if it is not already covered by another definition, could suddenly be claimed as part of mine development. Mine development is part of the actual mining. That is the definition that has operated and that is what the Federal Court has ruled on. As soon as mine development is included, someone will have a go at trying to define that in the broadest sense. They may actually claim the railway track being built to go to it is eligible for rebate when at the moment it is not. We are not expanding the scheme.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was not talking about any railway or any transportation. I was simply talking about developing a mine from exploration to the production stage, including such things as air shafts.
—Yes, the air shaft and so on.
—Nothing to do with transport.

TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are not prepared to stop the clarification attempt of the government in any of the categories. The general terms of what I will be saying will apply also to the amendments that the coalition parties are going to move. I think it is our argument that retrospective legislation, as such, is a legal terminology that must not be judged simply on the basis of that terminology. In fact, in some ways, we regret that the term retrospective has been used, when it is not appropriate in this case. Retrospectivity depends on the substance of the issue. I refer the Senate to the work of respected legal academic Professor Charles Sampford of Griffith University, who has recently conducted a major survey of the law of retrospective legislation in Australia. He has published his findings in the recent addition of the Federal Law Review.

PARA.TAB: He puts the argument that before we can treat that retrospective legislation as such—before we can put substance into that particular term—we must examine whether reliance on the legislation that is being changed has actually produced any substantive effects on the persons affected by the legislation. In other words: have persons, in the belief that the legislation was as it was, taken action which would put them at a disadvantage if that law is now clarified? Clearly, this test is not met in the current situation.

First of all, we do not have any clearly established body of law which allows people to make certain decisions, economic or otherwise, which define their interests. What we have here is a range of court cases which are under appeal. To save the time of the Senate I will not run through them again. I have mentioned them previously. Suffice it to say that the Neumann Sands case is on appeal to the Federal Court by the government, and the Nunawading City Council is appealing to the Federal Court against the decision that affects them. It is quite clear that we are in a situation of see-sawing legal definitions.

On the point of whether people have taken action in reliance on what they believe the law to be, we have not had any evidence at all that those people that believed they might have a right to obtain a rebate have in any way reduced their charges or the costs to their customers; nor have we received any commitment by any of these bodies, should they be successful at any future stage, to return to the end customer any of the benefits that they are seeking to obtain for themselves. We have here an attempt promoted by accountants and lawyers—by commissioned agents—to obtain benefits out of the public purse and to channel these benefits to people who believe they have found a legal loophole. That is really what we have.

It is a manoeuvre that is rather unsavoury, because we are talking about an amount of $160 million to $190 million. We are talking about that amount being extracted from the public purse to be channelled to people as a windfall profit, not in the normal course of their business transactions, and not as a result of decisions that they have made which now would disadvantage them. What we are being asked to do is to pass legislation which will provide a retrospective benefit. Let us call it by its proper name. It is a retrospective benefit that is now being asked for, and in that sense the term `retrospective' is well and truly justified.

When we look at the substance of this—when we look at $160 million to $190 million which would be syphoned out of the public purse—we should remind ourselves that $170 million is enough to provide nearly 400,000 person days of hospital care; that it is enough to build 300 new schools; that it is enough to clean up our polluted beaches many times over. Yet we get arguments here in the chamber that we should provide that retrospective benefit on the basis that some people thought their lawyers were finicky enough and clever enough to gain them an advantage in the court. The Democrats will not be part of it.

SPEECH.PARA: (4)If, in relation to a rebate application:
(a)legal proceedings have been brought in the Federal Court of Australia or the High Court of Australia before the day on which this Act receives the Royal Assent; and

That means that these individuals or companies went to the court on the basis of the law. They argued their cases before the AAT or the Federal Court and many of them were won. Now the government is changing the rules to override the decisions made in those courts.

PARA.TAB: I say to the government through the minister that this is the worst form of injustice that any parliament could impose. It is absolutely wrong. I say to you, Minister, and to Senator Spindler that you should think again about what you are doing with this legislation because it will come back to haunt you. TALK.START.PARA: —I agree with Senator Crane on one point: the government should have taken action a lot earlier and put the situation beyond doubt. PARA.TAB: To construct a legal argument and to take it to the courts on the see-saw of appeal and counter appeal, and then to say, `As a trading corporation, even if I have not put myself at a disadvantage by relying on this particular legislation, if I see an opportunity to grab $100 million, I will hop into the public purse and grab it' is not the sort of thing that our law, our parliamentary process, should be used for.
