As a result of the appearance of our companies at the Senate Economics Legislation Committee on Friday, it has come to our attention that the concept of `windfall gains' requires further explanation in the context of rebate claims made by our companies and relating to the industrial minerals sector. The issue as it applies to this sector needs to be divorced from matters relating to parks and gardens and other matters. Pertinent to these matters are issues already raised in prior correspondence which are not repeated here.
Dealings with Customs

It should be remembered that all the operations involving extraction of industrial minerals were covered by the diesel exemption scheme right up to 1982. Once the new scheme was introduced, negotiations with Customs commenced as to the eligibility of certain industrial minerals and it was generally accepted that silica sand, general sand and limestone were covered by the scheme. Claims on these minerals were lodged and paid from the inception of the scheme.

The treatment of other minerals was the subject of on-going consultation with Customs, resulting in legal action in the late l980s, in relation to the eligibility of clay, black granite and certain beneficiation operations in relation to limestone. Although the decisions in those cases were handed down in the late 1980s, as you can well imagine a significant period of time lapsed prior to the actual handing down of the court decisions, during which there was extensive consultation with Customs, preparation and lodgement of the claims, preparation and conducting of the hearings and delay in delivery of judgement. One of these cases involved a company in the Boral Group (Boral Bricks).
Following these decisions, Customs agreed to pay rebates in respect of clay and black granite, as well as sand and limestone, but continued to refuse to do so in respect of other industrial minerals.

In the interim, the decision of the AAT in Neumann Dredging was handed down in 1986, and on appeal to the Full Federal Court in 1987. In that case, dredging operations were undertaken for the purpose of increasing the depth of the river and the dredged sand was used for landfill. The mineral qualities of the sand were of little consequence and the Federal Court rightly concluded that the activities did not constitute mining operations. From that time, Customs mistakenly applied that decision to the effect that all sand extraction did not qualify for rebate. It is understood that Neumann Sands commenced negotiations with Customs as regards sand excavation for the mineral content of the sand and it was not until 1994 that the Neumann Sands case was actually heard by the AAT.
It can be seen from the above synopsis that this is not a matter of the companies having `sat on their hands' and not taken action, as has been claimed by Senator Schacht.

Allied to the above is the fact that claimants are generally reluctant to take court action against Government bodies (for fear of retribution and reasons of cost). Having brought four successful cases in seven years, it must be wondered how many more cases are required before Customs will commence giving effect to court decisions in its day-to-day administration. Customs refusal in this regard continues a long line of practice, publicly evidenced in a number of instances, most recently in the Midford paramount matter. As Justice Davies was moved to comment at the very outset of a 1989 Federal Court case:

"It has been rumoured for some time that the Collector of Customs has been reluctant to give effect to decisions of this court and of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal and of this court, reluctant to change a decision once made, and reluctant to give practical effect in monetary terms to a decision of this court or of the Tribunal which is contrary to a decision of the collector." (Collector of Customs v LNC (Wholesale) Pty Ltd (1989) 11 AAR 76)

Such practice is also evidenced by the fact that following the Neumann Sands decision Customs has paid rebate to the one claimant. Neumann Sands (refer Senate Estimates Committee p.E43, copy attached). In respect of identical sand operations for our companies, Customs has continued to refuse payment. Do claimants need to take legal action in respect of every similar sand operation in the county before Customs will acknowledge the eligibility of those operations?
Business Decision-Making Process
The question arose at the Senate Economics Legislation Committee on Friday as to the manner in which the companies have treated the expected rebates in their budgeting and pricing calculations.

The answer to that question is simple: to the extent that Customs had agreed that rebate was payable (ie in respect of clay, limestone and black granite), the companies did include the rebate in their budget and pricing calculations. In respect of other industrial minerals, where the companies have obtained advice that rebate was payable but where Customs' policy has been that such activities are ineligible, the companies have not done so.

The answer to this question, however, needs to be understood in the context of the caution which underlies all business decision-making. It would be a very brave (and possibly foolish) businessman indeed who would budget on the basis that a rebate would be payable where the policy of the Government body concerned was that the rebate was not payable. In these circumstances, no matter how strong the legal advice, there is no certainty as to the obtaining of payment, and particularly as to the timing of the receipt of the payment and the lengths (and therefore costs) which will need to be undertaken in obtaining payment.

All of this, however, does not detract from the fact that the companies have believed that an entitlement has existed for some time and have been mindful of such an entitlement in the general operation of their businesses.
The fact of the matter is that the companies have a legal entitlement which they have been aware of for some time but which Customs has refused to acknowledge.
Concept of Mining
Finally, we would like to make one very obvious point in relation to Senator Schacht's comments that the activities in question were not intended to be part of the scheme as originally envisaged.

The simple fact is that the intention of the scheme was to cover `mining operations', as that term is accepted in industry. Senator the Hon Cheryl Kernot
Leader, The Australian Democrats
Parliament House
CANBERRA ACT 2900
Dear Senator,
DIESEL FUEL REBATE—WINDFALL GAIN ASPECTS

Thank you for meeting with representative of Boral, Pioneer and CSR on 29 May 1995. At that meeting we undertook to supply you and your advisers with further information and we will provide that later in this letter.
But first we would like to further address the issue of retrospectivity, which is a critical part of the Bill.

We believe we have made clear our companies' absolute opposition to the use of such legislation. In support of our position, we would draw your attention to the view of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills in its alert digest of 31 May 1995 on the Bill.

In commenting on the proposal to amend the law retrospectively, the Committee says, "This clearly trespasses on the basic right that those subject to the law are entitled to be treated according to what the law says at the relevant time and according to what the law means at that time as declared by the courts."

We would also draw your attention to a 6 June 1995 statement by the Business Council of Australia which describes the retrospective proposal as "wrong in principle, discriminatory and exposes Australia to changes of heightened sovereign risk".
On the issue of retrospectivity we have become concerned at statements by the responsible Minister, Senator Schacht, in support of the legislation.

In order to defend the indefensible, Senator Schacht is joining a number of issues in order to confuse the situation—in particular by representing the Government's actions `closing off a proposal for people to get a windfall gain for activities they conducted nine years ago' (Senate p1147, 8 June 1995) and claiming it would cost $170 million.

Pioneer, Boral and CSR wish to make their position absolutely clear: This is not a matter of windfall gains engineered for them by so-called industry `consultants', as described by Senator Schacht, for claims lodged just before and after the Budget.
Instead, what is at risk for the companies are payments for claims, for which Notices of Intention to lodge, were made prior to 30 June 1994.

Indeed, the companies have lodged and been paid for similar claims going back several years. If the Government believed these claims were outside the original intent of the Scheme, it should have acted in l989 when the first judicial decision went against the Australian Customs Service (ACS).
Some of the claims lodged prior to the Budget were subject to misleading undertakings given by the ACS.
Pioneer's position may give you an idea of how the Government proposes to deny companies their dues and how the ACS has behaved in the matter.

Pioneer lodged claims in May 1994 and was involved in extensive discussions with Customs. After first being advised that its claims would be accepted and paid, it was later notified that claims were to be deferred as a precedent case was pending (the first it knew of Neumann Sands case). Pioneer proceeded to lodge claims in relation to all of its sites prior to the end of June 1994 and agreed with Customs' suggestion that a decision on those claims be deferred until the AAT decided the Neumann case. When that case was decided in February, Customs advised Pioneer that an appeal to the Federal Court had been lodged and that its claims would be determined on the basis of that appeal. On 9 May 1995 the Minister announced the retrospective legislation and on 10 May Pioneer received notice that its claims were to be denied.

Before proceeding to consider other matters, it is important to understand from the outset that the matters raised here relate to the treatment of industrial minerals. The appropriate treatment of other issues (such as parks and gardens, water supply, etc), and the background to such matters, is a totally separate matter. The Government appears to be keen to `muddy the waters' on these distinct issues.
Original Intention
In the 29 May discussions you asked for our view on the original intention of the legislation.

A copy of the 1982 Explanatory Memorandum and Second Reading Speech can be found at Attachment A. Other material makes reference to alterations in the treatment of specific industry sectors (eg railways) but this does not impact on the treatment of industrial minerals.

The Government has stated that the proposed changes outlined in the Budget context (including those relating to industrial minerals) reflect the original intent of the legislation. But this is not the case.

Prior to 1982, a certificate scheme operated to provide up-front exemption for diesel fuel purchased for off-road use. Under that Scheme a purchaser could quote a certificate time of purchase of the diesel fuel and obtain exemption by way of an excise-free price.

As indicated in the attached 1982 documentation, this Scheme was very much subject to abuse as it fundamentally relied on honesty in providing certificates in the appropriate circumstances. With effect from 1982, the Government introduced a scheme aimed at preventing this abuse through identifying those industries/uses which it could be expected that vehicles would be used off-road. In the Second Reading Speech of Mr Hodgman (the then Minister for Capital Territory and Minister assisting the Minister for Industry and Commerce), in the context of talking about the new Scheme, said:

`The categories I have just referred to relate to the use of diesel fuel in the agriculture, mining, forestry and fishing industries, in domestic premises, hospitals, aged persons homes and nursing homes. The overriding qualification for rebate will be that the fuel so used will be used otherwise than for the purposes of propelling a road vehicle on a public road."
(emphasis added)

It will be seen from this passage and indeed the general comments made in the attached documentation that the overriding purpose of the changes in 1982 was not to change the fundamental scope of the Scheme but rather to prevent the abuse in question.

The companies were in fact entitled to exemption under that original Scheme. Further, in the operations involving the extraction of industrial minerals, the use of diesel fuel is virtually always in respect of equipment used or propelled otherwise than on a public road. This much is supported by the decisions of the courts in relation to certain clay, limestone, black granite and sand (from 1988 onwards) and is clearly contrary to the comments made by the Government in the Budget documents.
Concept of Mining

It will be seen from the attached definitions that the concept of `minerals' is generally sufficiently broad to encompass activities associated with the extraction of clay, limestone, sand, granite, basalt and dolomite when recovered to harness their inherent mineral properties. Indeed, in many instances, these substances are specifically mentioned as falling within the definition. A ready example can be found in the Commonwealth legislation (the first definition found at Attachment B).
The facts that the extraction of industrial minerals can be categorised as `mining' is evident from the following:

PARA.TAB: in many cases, the activities in question operate in direct competition with traditional open-cut mines. It is clearly inequitable that the traditional mines would receive the DFR benefit while the operations in question would not;
the development of technology, geological science and the use of minerals has meant that it has become virtually impossible to distinguish between mining and quarrying operations;
the activities in question operate under the mining leases in most States;
the activities in question are treated as mining for other revenue purposes.

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the day, what the companies in question are doing is, as a matter of fact, mining for minerals.
The Facts
There has been a number of confusing comments made in relation to the proposed amendments. The facts in relation to the treatment of industrial minerals need to be clarified.

Fact 1—The original intention of the Scheme as evidenced in the attached 1982 material was to provide rebate for fuel used in off-road applications. This was achieved through the identification of certain industries and uses (including `mining') being those uses where equipment is ordinarily used off-road.

Fact 2—The only exclusion in the relevant legislation which relates to quarrying activities is to `quarrying operations carried on for the sole purpose of obtaining stone for building, road making or similar purposes'. The cases have confirmed that it is clear from this exclusion that other quarrying operations (ie those which are the subject of the amendments in question) are intended to be covered.

Fact 3—DFR has traditionally been claimed retrospectively, following the consumption of the diesel fuel. It is not uncommon for companies to delay claims for a number of years. This traditional approach has largely stemmed from the fact that, up until 1994, retrospective claims could be made as far back as August 1986 and indexation of rates means that claimants are not penalised through delaying lodgement of claims.

Fact 4—In addition to the above, the DFR legislation has not been clearly understood and this has led to at least eight cases over a period of seven years, as well as changing ACS treatment and policy.

Fact 5—Claims in respect of sand extraction have been lodged and paid since the early 1980s. Consequent upon the decision in Neumann Sands, and despite the fact that that decision found in favour of the applicant, the ACS has ceased paying such claims. Sand is one of the minerals which will be excluded if the Bill is passed through Parliament.

Fact 6—Claims in respect of clay extraction have been lodged prior to 1989, and certainly lodged since that date, pursuant to the decision in the Boral Bricks Case. That company is of course one of the companies within the Boral Group. Clay is one of the minerals which will be excluded if the Bill is passed through Parliament.

Fact 7—Claims in respect of limestone extraction have been lodged and paid well before 1989 when the matter of beneficiation was examined in the Adelaide Brighton Case. Limestone is one of the minerals which will be excluded if the bill is passed through Parliament.

Fact 8—Claims in respect of black granite have been made and claimed since 1988, pursuant to the decision in the Bell Basic Case. Black granite is one of the minerals which will be excluded if the Bill is passed through Parliament.
Fact 9—Claims in respect of aggregate extraction have been lodged and paid in respect of diesel used since August 1986.
Fact 10—A number of claims for other minerals have been lodged over the last 12 months, many in May and June 1994.

Fact 11—With effect from 1 July 1994, the Government amended the legislation so that retrospective claims could only be made going back three years. All the companies in question lodged Notices of Intention prior to 30 June 1994 to protect their entitlements going back to August 1986. The companies are aware of a number of other companies who similarly lodged Notices of Intention.

Fact 12—Over the last 12 months, the ACS has refused to pay some claims on the basis that the decision in Neumann Sands would further clarify the scope of the relevant legislation, not only in respect of sand mining but also other operations. Following the ACS decision to appeal Neumann Sands, the ACS has again refused to process the claims in question.

Fact 13—Legislative definitions of `minerals' at Attachment B encompass the industrial minerals in question and there is now no distinction between traditional open-cut mining and the operations in question.

It will be seen from the above facts that this is not by any account a situation where claims have been lodged since February 1995 with the expectation of obtaining a large benefit, which the companies only became aware of following both the Neumann Sands decision and the media rumours relating to possible changes to the DFR Scheme. To summarise the above facts:

PARA.TAB: the operations in question do fall within the original intention of the Scheme;
the companies in question, as well as other companies, have been making claims in respect of sand, clay, limestone and aggregate during the 1980s and since then; and

the companies in question, as well as other companies, did lodge claims or Notices of Intention prior to 30 June 1994 on the basis of a clear understanding that there were remaining operations which were eligible and which had not been claimed.

SPEECH.PARA: While the exact scope of the Scheme has never been clear (as is evidenced by the number of court decisions), it is clear from the above facts that the companies have been aware of an entitlement which could be pursued at a convenient time.

To the extent that there was a rush of claims prior to the Budget, this was indeed due to rumours associated with potential changes in the Budget but consequent upon the Notices of Intention lodged in June 1994. The Budget rumours merely brought forward action which the companies had clearly intended taking for some time.

The operation of the DFR Scheme can be contrasted with provisions of the various Bounty Acts (also administered by the Customs authorities). In the later instance there is a clearly defined period in which claims must be lodged. This has not been the case with the DFR Scheme up until the 1994 amendments.

Any delay in lodging claims also needs to be considered in the context of the ACS's changing policy. The ACS has generally been reluctant to acknowledge that the DFR Scheme includes certain industrial minerals. This is despite the original intention and also despite the on-going case law. After each case, the ACS has changed its policy but only to allow rebate on the actual minerals which were the subject of that case. Companies are generally reluctant to offend a Government body by taking legal action—but obviously have been forced to do so in the cases to date.
Further, as indicated above, some of the claims lodged prior to the Budget were subject to misleading undertakings given by the ACS.
Parks and Gardens and Water Supply

As we have said, it is important to distinguish between operations associated with the extraction of industrial minerals and other proposed amendments dealing with parks and gardens, water supply and other matters. It is unusual that the Government has sought to amend the legislation for parks and gardens in light of the fact that the only relevant decision (being City of Nunawading and Comptroller General of Customs) found in favour of the ACS. Nonetheless, the Government's policy on the above matters is a totally separate issue.
Response to Government Claims

In the Financial Review of 8 June 1995, Senator Schacht is reported as making certain claims in relation to the operation of the DFR Scheme. Relevant extracts from that article are quoted below with the following comments indicating the correct position:

`. . . most (claims) have been lodged only since February as accountancy firms and consultancies have realised the extent of loopholes allowing a broad range of activities to be classified as `connected with' agriculture and mining, thus qualifying for the rebate.'

It is important in this context to distinguish the various categories of claims and to remember that the issues for this purpose relate only to the extraction of industrial minerals. In that context, the following reply is warranted:

PARA.TAB: as indicated, a vary large number of claims have been lodged over an extensive period in respect of sand, clay, limestone and granite. As a result of Budget speculation, it is true that many (but certainly not most) claims were lodged prior to Budget night in an attempt to ensure hat the companies in question maintained their legal rights;

in the context of industrial minerals, it will be seen from the list of court cases which have been handed down since l988 that this is not a matter of accountancy firms and consultancies realising the `extent of loopholes'. The companies in question take offence at the concept that claims in respect of industrial minerals (which are after all no different to extraction of other minerals such as coal, iron ore and bauxite) constitutes a `loophole'; and

certain aspects of the proposed amendments do relate to the question of whether activities are `connected with' agriculture or mining. The issue here, however, is simply whether such activities are in fact `mining' (and not whether they are `connected with' mining).
In the context of industrial minerals, the courts have consistently held, since 1988, that they should be part of the DFR Scheme.
The decision in Nunawading which deals with the treatment of parks and gardens in fact found in favour of the ACS.

The implication may be gained from this and other aspects of Senator Schacht's comments that accountancy and consulting firms are approaching claimants and operating on a success fee basis. Senator Schacht has already been informed that in the case of work undertaken by Arthur Andersen and Coopers & Lybrand for the companies in question, that this is simply not the case.

"Other changes would exclude quarrying from the mining provisions . . . This, says the Government, would return the interpretation of the Act to that for which it was intended and which, until recently, have been upheld in the appeals process."
As indicated elsewhere, it can be seen from the l982 Parliamentary material that it was clearly not intended that operations here would be excluded; and

once again, the idea that the appeals process has upheld this approach until `recently' is simply outrageous. The courts have consistently held since 1988 that the extraction of industrial minerals is part of the DFR Scheme. There is no plausible reason as to why it should not continue to be treated in such a manner.

SPEECH.PARA: Finally, Senator Schacht has separately claimed that a large portion of the outstanding claims relate to sand extraction. Examination of the companies' own records demonstrate that in fact sand and sand related activities represent a minority of claims.
Conclusion
In summary, the senator should be aware that:

PARA.TAB: the retrospective nature of the Bill is unprecedented;
the manner in which the Bill seeks to interfere with legal proceedings is unprecedented;
the extraction of industrial minerals are, for all intents and purposes, treated in the industry as `mining operations' and to exclude such operations from the DFR Scheme would result in inequities;
claims in respect of certain industrial minerals have been lodged and paid since the introduction of the Scheme.
the treatment of parks and gardens and water supply is a totally separate issue to that relating to industrial minerals.

SPEECH.PARA: These concerns can be easily rectified by amending the Bill to:

PARA.TAB: delete the proposed definition of `minerals'; and
remove the Bill's retrospectivity.

—I probably could have managed; but there would be a lot of other people in that category. One thing that Senator Schacht's outburst has achieved is to encourage me to have a closer look at some of the legislation that the Labor Party has put through, to see how many of its members—
—The Prime Minister, in relation to quarantine laws and so forth—

—Yes, in relation to pig things. I thank Senator Schacht because I had forgotten about this matter, as we had all disclosed our interests. I might make it an exercise to go back and see which pieces of legislation Labor senators have all voted for. I can go through the registers and see how many of them have declared these sorts of things. I am grateful to Senator Schacht for raising that in such a public way because it might provide a little fun for some of our researchers during the recess looking to see how many Labor Party politicians have complied.

TALKER.NAME: Senator SCHACHT
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Small Business, Customs and Construction)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to put on record for Senator Crane the question of whether any diesel fuel rebate had been paid for the building of a train line associated with a mining project. I have now been informed that a check of the records—and about 200,000 claims are made every year—showed that a claim was paid for the Brockman Spur line. I have said to you in the debate that we wanted to exclude railway claims like that. That was put to you very clearly.
—Is that to do with the construction?

—It was about the construction of the Brockman Spur line. The rebate was paid. Customs officers advised me that this was paid in error and should not have been paid. They accept that an error was made. I have to point out that when one is dealing with over 200,000 applications for rebates per year, from time to time there will be an error. We are not in the business of reclaiming the rebate. It has been paid, but it certainly was not within the policy guidelines.

PARA.TAB: Senator, I wanted to put that on the record to clarify the remarks I made. Someone may be able to produce this particular case but it was made in error—and we apologise for that. There are 140 people in Customs dealing with over 200,000 applications a year. There is always going to be the odd chance for an error here or there.

I want to make a brief comment about the remarks just made by some senators. We are waiting for the drafting of the amendment to complete this debate. As soon as it is available—and it is being drafted now in agreement with Senator Margetts and government advisers—the matter will be put and that will be the end of the debate. A number of senators made remarks about my press statement last night and the general remarks I made about the retrospectivity clause as it affects three companies.

I think it is reasonable to draw it to the attention of senators that when they vote in this place on those retrospectivity clauses, where over $70 million will be going to three companies which have publicly and openly lobbied for the rebates, there is no doubt that that is beyond what we normally vote for here, such as social security benefits or whatever. Voting on a Medicare bill, for example, is different—we all get access to Medicare in one form or another.

This is a special case where three companies—if this legislation is defeated and the court upholds their appeal—will get between $70 million and $90 million in windfall gain. They have already charged their customers for the product, based on the full cost of diesel. They have given no indication that they will repay the money to the customers or reduce their prices. I presume it will go to the shareholders or be retained and advance the value of the company. Therefore, anybody who does own shares in that company will, in my view, stand to gain. I thought it was only reasonable to raise this issue before the vote.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did you say their obligation under the orders was to declare their interest?
—I did not say that.
—What did you say?
—I went through a public document called `Declaration of pecuniary interests'. I now know why, for so long, the Liberal Party opposed the establishment of a pecuniary interests register.

PARA.TAB: I raised this issue to remind people to declare their interests before the vote. If the vote took place and someone did not declare an interest and half a day later someone jumped up, you would have accused us of creating an ambush. I thought it was appropriate to draw the matter to the attention of honourable senators. I did it in a way that gave everybody an opportunity to declare their interest, including members on our side of the chamber.

The final aspect is that I own an apartment that is part of a ski lodge at Falls Creek. It is on the declaration of pecuniary interests. I do not know whether the lodge uses diesel fuel for heating or whether they claim the diesel fuel rebate. However, if ski lodges are getting the diesel fuel rebate, that rebate will be removed by this legislation. So, in voting on this bill, I will certainly be voting against my own interest, if that building does get some diesel fuel rebate—and I do not know whether they do or not. I did this quite openly to bring it to the attention of honourable members.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—Senator Schacht has been caught out in a most sleazy attempt to attack members on this side of the chamber. It was only a matter of weeks ago that we tabled a report which, among other things, considered whether the Prime Minister, Mr Keating, should declare changes in his assets, investments and borrowings each year. That is very important. Mr Keating is an immensely wealthy man. He is arguably the wealthiest Prime Minister in Australian history. As he has told us so many times, he has his hands on the levers.

PARA.TAB: Senator Schacht's colleagues on that committee opposed any additional disclosure arrangements for the Prime Minister. Last night, Senator Schacht attempted to embarrass people on this side of the chamber. Unfortunately, he kicked his own goal, as he often does. But it reminded me that when we sought what is regarded in most countries as a perfectly reasonable step, that the leaders of our country declare each year changes in their assets, borrowings and liabilities, members on your side of the chamber, Senator Schacht, vigorously opposed it.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—There are two reasons why I am not sure whether I need to make a declaration. Firstly, I have a family company which has an extensive portfolio of shares in companies, one of which was mentioned this afternoon. Those shares are not in my name but that of the family company. When I made my declaration on the register, I actually put down the shares that that family company holds. I do not think I necessarily had to do that; but I do declare that the family company has shares in at least one of the companies mentioned this afternoon.

PARA.TAB: Secondly, I am voting with the government's proposal, which would disadvantage the particular company to which I refer. But I make the declaration in case I do have to make it. The particular shares that I refer to are listed in the register under my name.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—There are certain standards in public life and in behaviour in this chamber. Senator Schacht clearly transgressed those because he presumed that the people on this side of the chamber would not have the sense of responsibility to make the declarations at the requisite time.

PARA.TAB: There is nothing more nauseating than the Australian Labor Party when they get this mantle of sanctimony. You have a Prime Minister (Mr Keating) who has reduced the economy of this country to something similar to Mexico. And, like a Mexican president, he entered politics without any money and will retire a multi-millionaire.

I have to make a declaration. I do not know whether the company is affected but the only shares I hold are in Kidston Gold Mines. They may be a beneficiary under this, I do not know. I am quite happy to put that on the record because it is in my declaration of interests. The only reason I hold those shares is because I mislaid my stock certificate many years ago.

I have a view that my private affairs are my private affairs. Some years ago I sold all my shareholdings because I just was not going to be put in the position of having my integrity impugned in debate by people like Senator Schacht. So I sold everything and I held the Kidston ones simply because I lost the stock certificate and I have never gotten around to making a statutory declaration and getting a new certificate of registration from the company.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave—At the hearings the other day I declared an interest in these proceedings as a farmer through my family's interest in farming. May be I should make a similar declaration in this debate. I do not know how many times you need to repeat these things. I also declare interests in SBS Rural, Wesfarmers, Cooperative Bulk Handling, Rural Traders and one or two others; I do not remember them all now. They are all written on my form. I do not know whether they will get a benefit out of it or not.

PARA.TAB: The distribution last night of the press statement in the gallery was the lowest form of sleaze that I have seen since I have been here. If Senator Schacht was genuine in what he wanted to do, he would have come into this particular debate and said, `I would like to remind senators of this particular fact'.

That press statement was not sent to senators. I did not receive one. I got one from a journalist who sent it down to me. It was not intended to come to me. I do not believe that it was intended to come to anyone in this place. It was a stunt by Senator Schacht to score a cheap shot.

Last week at the hearings representatives of either Pioneer Boral or CSR—it will be on the record—did answer the question of how the money would be distributed if any of the rebate was paid back. They said—and Senator Panizza was there—that any moneys that came back in would be shared between lower prices to the customer, investment and the shareholders.

So it is no good for Senator Schacht to stand over there and say that the companies have not commented on it. I draw Senator Schacht's attention to page three of the letter that I tabled today, or had incorporated, with regard to those companies addressing that particular aspect of it. I also draw his attention to their submission to the committee.

I want to highlight the point that the answer to the question is simple: they said that, to the extent that Customs had agreed that the rebate was payable, that is, clay, limestone and black granite, the companies did include the rebate in their budget and pricing calculations. Having won their cases in the Federal Court and having budgeted for it, they have now not been paid. It is on the public record now in Hansard, but it is a misrepresentation of what occurred at the hearing last week and the existing facts.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair—
—Senator Short, you have made a declaration. If you wish to speak again, you will need leave.
—I seek leave to make a relatively brief response to the minister's ungraceful refusal to apologise.
—How long will you be?
—About two or three minutes.

PARA.TAB: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not surprised but I am amazed that the minister refuses to make an apology to those senators against whom he behaved so poorly and with bad grace and impropriety yesterday. I do not know his motive. There can be only two motives for what he did. One explanation may be ignorance; he did not know the relevant standing order. For his edification, let me read the relevant standing order:

TAB.EMPHASIS: 5. Declaration of interest in debate and other proceedings

SPEECH.PARA: That, notwithstanding the lodgment by a Senator of a statement of the Senator's registrable interests and the registrable interests of which the Senator is aware (a) of the Senator's spouse; and (b) of any children who are wholly or mainly dependent on the Senator for support, and the incorporation of that statement in a Register of Senators' Interests, a Senator shall declare any relevant interest:

PARA.TAB: (a) at the beginning of his or her speech if the Senator participates in debate in the Senate, committee of the whole Senate, or a committee of the Senate or of the Senate and the House of Representatives, and

(b) as soon as practicable after a division is called for in the Senate, committee of the whole Senate, or a committee of the Senate or of the Senate and the House of Representatives, if the Senator proposes to vote in that division.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Hill and others have said, the statement that went out by Senator Schacht yesterday was well in advance of any of the opportunities that the relevant senators had to declare an interest. I am not too sure of the definition of `relevant'. As far as I am aware, all of us who have made a declaration have done so at the first appropriate, available opportunity. It could have been ignorance on the minister's part. That would not surprise me in the slightest.

PARA.TAB: If he was aware of the rules, the only motive one can reasonably attribute to the minister was an attempt—I do not think this word is too strong—to blackmail senators and to influence their vote in this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Chair, I take a point of order. I know there is supposed to be robust debate at any time, but I wonder whether `blackmail' is unparliamentary.
—My impression was that Senator Short suggested that your conduct suggested blackmail. I do not know that he accused you of blackmail.

—The actions that he took yesterday were quite clearly designed to influence before a vote and in a totally improper way senators in their intentions. I think that is disgraceful. I think it is totally improper.
—Jim, you've got about a minute left.

—I have got a minute to go. I am amazed that Senator Schacht refuses to make that apology. I do not know what sort of a precedent he thinks he has set here. You and many of your colleagues belong to trade unions. Many of you pay your dues to trade unions. Even if you do not there is an—
—Association.

—It is more than an association, it is a binding link between the trade union movement and the Labor Party. Are you going to get up every time there is an industrial relations bill in this chamber and declare a relevant interest because of the trade union involvement? Particularly if you are a member of a trade union, are you going to refuse to vote or declare an interest when an industrial relations bill is before the chamber?

—Madam Chair, I take a point of order. Leave was given to Senator Short by me in the interests of seeing this matter concluded as quickly as possible. That was the sensible course of action in the circumstances. The clock was set to allow Senator Short the three minutes he requested. He has gone well beyond that. I would ask you to ask him to conclude his remarks. We have an enormous amount of business to deal with in a very short period of time.

—On the point of order: I understood that leave was given to Senator Short. I do not think there is any provision in the standing orders for leave to be given to speak for a period of time. Senator Short is obviously concluding his remarks. For the minister to take a point of order is simply delaying the chamber yet again.
—It is very churlish.
—It is very churlish. We have a lot of business to get through. These continuous interruptions by the Labor Party do not help.
—Have you concluded, Senator Short?

—I am winding up. I will be 20 or 25 seconds. I make the point very seriously that there are some very important issues of principle involved. There are potential conflicts of interest day in, day out as far as members of the government are concerned through their association with or membership of trade unions. I do not think anyone would have reasonably expected them to declare a relevant interest every time. I have never seen any of them do it on any bill. I put to Senator Schacht that when the parliament resumes we on this side will be looking very closely at the conflicts of interest that arise time and time again when you bring before the Senate legislation which affects your own vested interest in the labour movement.
—by leave—I declare an interest as a diesel fuel user. I declare a further interest in that I hold various mining shares. I also declare the interest of my family superannuation fund in shares.
—by leave—I wish to make an additional declaration. As a grazier, I certainly use diesel fuel. I did not think it was affected by this bill. In light of what Senator Panizza said, I think it might.

—by leave—I am afraid that I am confused about this matter. I did disclose some interest in some shares that my wife has in MIM. I would like Mr Keating to declare his interests. As my friend Senator Kemp said, Mr Keating started his parliamentary career with nothing. He is now able to afford a $2 million mansion in one of the very best suburbs in Sydney.
—Astute investments.

—Astute investments, perhaps in shares that get some benefit out of a lot of the legislation that has been through the parliament in the last 12 years. I do not think Mr Keating has ever indicated a conflict of interest. Someone can correct me if I am wrong. Maybe I am wrong. Maybe he has.

PARA.TAB: That reminded me that, like Mr Keating, I am human. My shareholdings are absolutely minute. I seem to recall that I have some shares in ANI, regrettably I might say in view of recent share movements. I suspect ANI uses diesel fuel. I suspect it has subsidiary companies which are in mining. It is a big conglomerate. It probably has shares in mining companies. It probably has something to do with brick making. I am not too sure. I do not want to be the butt of one of Senator Schacht's vicious, sleazy press releases in the future. Therefore, I declare this interest in ANI.
I think my family company has a few shareholdings in some pretty poor mining companies. Again, I say that with some regret.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you want to adjourn the debate so you can go and check the list?

—Senator Hill says that perhaps I should seek leave to adjourn my statement of declaration so that I can check the list and make sure that I, unlike Mr Keating, do not forget some things. For what it is worth and for any that I might have, I declare an interest now.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Margetts Sen D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Deputy President—
—Senator Margetts, what are your shareholdings?
—I declare that I have no shareholdings.
—Have you got a yacht?

—Not even a dinghy. In the non-amendment break that we have just had, there has been discussion between my office and the advisers to work out new wording. I seek leave to move amendments Nos 1, 2 and 3 which have been circulated on a piece of hand-written, photocopied paper.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1)Clause 2, page 2, subclause 2, lines 1 and 2, omit the subclause, substitute the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(2) Items 4, 7 (only insofar as that item refers to water) and items 8 and 10 of Schedule 1 are taken to have commenced on 1 August 1986.".

SPEECH.PARA: (2)Clause 2, page 2, subclause 3, lines 3 and 4, omit the subclause, substitute the following subclause:

PARA.TAB: "(3) Items 1, 5, 6, 7 (insofar as that item refers to sand, sandstone, soil, slate, clay (other than bentonite and kaolin), basalt, granite, gravel and limestone) and item 9 of Schedule 1, and Schedule 2, commence on 1 July 1995.".

Clause 5, page 3, subparagraph (3)(iii), omit the subparagraph, substitute the following subparagraph:

"(iii)the amendments set out in items 1, 5, 6, 7 (insofar as that item refers to sand, sandstone, soil, slate, clay (other than bentonite or kaolin), basalt, granite, gravel and limestone) and item 9 of Schedule 1, and Schedule 2, had not been made; and".

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to debate these amendments. I want an absolute clarification from Senator Margetts and the minister, with the advice of his advisers, about the drafting of these amendments. We have not had any time to look at them and assess what they really mean. Do they mean that retrospectivity will not apply to activities loosely described as quarrying?

—Amendments Nos 1, 2 and 3 perform exactly the same functions as my amendments Nos 1 to 5. That means that retrospectivity will not apply to quarrying. I have complied with the request to make the amendments more workable.

—I understand that quarrying will not be retrospective. Will those cases that are now before the courts or those applications that were put in under the notice of intent requirements—they had to be in prior to 1 July 1994—be dealt with under the new provisions of the act, or will they be dealt with under the old provisions up to this date?
—They are under the effect of the amendment under the old provision.

PARA.TAB: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Margetts's) be agreed to.
Question so resolved in the affirmative.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

DEBATE.TITLE: MINISTER FOR HUMAN SERVICES AND HEALTH

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chamarette Sen C.M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to contingent notice, I move:

PARA.TAB: That so much of the standing orders be suspended as would prevent her moving a motion to provide for the consideration of a matter, namely a motion to give precedence to a motion to defer further consideration of the Government Business order of the day relating to the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill 1995 until the Minister representing the Attorney-General (Senator Bolkus) purges his comtempt of the Senate by tabling all remaining documents required by the order for the production of documents agreed to by the Senate on 28 June 1995.

SPEECH.PARA: I am moving this suspension as a matter of urgency. Senator Bolkus, the Minister representing the Attorney-General has now been in contempt of the Senate for over 24 hours because he has failed to fully comply with the terms of the return to order passed by the Senate yesterday afternoon. As I said yesterday, for the second time in a month the government has used a very narrow definition of what it is required to table under a return to order to exclude any document which may be damaging to its cause. The Senate has always taken a grave view of the contempt shown to it by ministers who fail to comply with returns to order. In recent times many of the non-government senators who have succeeded in getting returns to order agreed to by the Senate have been lenient on the minister in this regard, and there is a limit, particularly when the contempt is as profound as it is today.

PARA.TAB: Let us make some things clear. The Marks royal commission is not a Commonwealth commission or a Commonwealth inquiry. The three examples that the government used to justify its funding the case in the statement tabled by the minister yesterday are all cases involving Commonwealth commissions of inquiry about matters relating to Commonwealth issues. This is a WA state matter and involves matters which relate to the actions or knowledge of Dr Carmen Lawrence in her role as the Premier of Western Australia. It does not involve matters that in any way relate to her current role as the federal Minister for Human Services and Health. As I said yesterday, if it did she would be covered by the guidelines for the provision of assistance to Commonwealth government ministers and parliamentary secretaries in relation to the defence of legal proceedings.

What is more, the government has provided no substantial argument for why the case should be funded because it involves important points of constitutional law or federal state relations. I suspect the reason for not providing the arguments is that there are none.

I believe the government is unwilling to provide the documents which provide the advice from the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Finance on whether Dr Lawrence's case fits in with the current guidelines because the case clearly does not. The onus is now very much on the government and the minister to answer why it has agreed to provide funding for this action. The onus is on the government to answer why it is providing funding for a federal minister in circumstances where, to the best of my knowledge, no other individual has ever been provided with assistance.

I have said already that the Minister representing the Attorney-General has now been in contempt of the Senate for over 24 hours. For this reason, I believe that proceeding with or calling on the bill of the Attorney-General, which we were about to do, while he remains in contempt of the Senate is inappropriate. That is why it is urgent that we consider whether we once again may be allowing the integrity and authority of the Senate to be undermined. I urge my colleagues to support the suspension to debate this matter.

TALKER.NAME: Senator HILL
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think two matters ought to be dealt with before we would be prepared to support a suspension of standing orders. There is a lot of merit in what Senator Chamarette says. The behaviour of Senator Bolkus is absolutely appalling. He is in contempt of the Senate, and that is a very serious matter. He laughs it off, but if we allow him to laugh it off without taking any action then he will do it again. However, there is a message from the House of Representatives regarding the taxation bill. As members of the House are waiting to deal with that bill, and as I understand it is a very brief debate, it ought to be dealt with before we debate Senator Bolkus's behaviour. Secondly, there is the longstanding matter of Senator Patterson's private member's bill, which I gather is a one-minute job. We will not support the suspension at the moment. If we can deal with these two matters quickly, then we would be of a mind to support Senator Chamarette's motion if she wished to re-move it at that time.

TALKER.NAME: Senator FAULKNER
TALKER.ROLE: Manager of Government Business in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —Naturally, the government will not support this particular proposal. There are not only the matters that Senator Hill referred to but also a range of very significant bills to which commitments have been given to deal with before the Senate gets up. I can assure you that the government will not be resiling from the necessity to deal with the noise measures that are contained in the Aircraft Noise Levy Bill 1995 and the Aircraft Noise Levy Collection Bill 1995. There are very significant social security benefits in a package before the Senate. The significance of the First Corporate Law Simplification Bill and what Senator Hill said in relation to the Taxation Laws Amendment Bill (No. 1) 1995 is true. We do have a responsibility to deal with these matters. If there is not time to do it before 3.45 p.m., then the Senate should sit long enough to complete the urgent business that is before it tonight.
—Have you got enough people there?

—Yes, we have. The government is keen to do that and will propose to do so. It might require a little more effort on the part of the Senate to fulfil its legislative responsibilities and the commitments that have been given in relation to these matters. That will be the position that the government will take. We oppose this very disruptive proposition to up-end the processes in relation to Senate business.

TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Australian Democrats)

TALK.START.PARA: —I concur with the comments of Senator Hill. I do not think this is the best time to debate the motion, although I acknowledge it is a very important issue.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is a pity that we cannot deliver this to small business but I guess that, for some small businesses, the fact that we have not proceeded with the extension of the sales tax on building materials will be of assistance. I put that on the record and acknowledge that it is a diversion, but it is an important one because Senator Short is saying he is going to review this in government. Just in case we are still here in 90 days, I want to hear this present government say that it will seriously review the recommendations of the Economics Committee on the taxation of small business.

TALK.START.PARA: —Last night I was talking about Australian Defence Industries and was preparing to reveal how Australian Defence Industries has been selling arms to Papua New Guinea to prop up the war in Bougainville. I recalled that, if we sell Australian Defence Industries, the government loses accountability for Australian Defence Industries' role in the arms trade. The ethical amongst us would probably like to see a government concerned with human rights abuses in its region getting right out of the business that deals in death and destruction to its region's minority groups.

PARA.TAB: The government might like to rid itself of Australian Defence Industries to excuse itself of its hypocrisies. However, if ADI is sold off—obviously the most lucrative sections of the company would be sold first—the government and the Australian people will have less idea about what goes on at ADI and ADI's role in the regional arms trade than ever before. ADI will be able to shield even more behind commercial in confidence and hide its sales and export figures. Parliament will have less ability to scrutinise what has been manufactured and what we are exporting to our neighbours, with inadequate export guidelines.

Over the last few months, a Victorian human rights organisation called Australian Humanitarian Aid for Bougainville has been researching the links between Australian Defence Industries and the war in Bougainville. It was claimed at the national women's peace camp in April, at the ADI munitions factory in Benalla, that ADI weaponry is used in the war in Bougainville. This is a long running seven-year war in which over 5,000 people have been killed.

Australia has been active in supporting the war in Bougainville, due to our special defence relationship with Papua New Guinea and to protect our economic interests in the form of the Australian company CRA, a subsidiary of multinational Rio Tinto Zinc, RTZ, which owns the Bougainville copper mine where the war began. The Australian Defence Force has trained over 3,000 members of the Papua New Guinea defence force since 1975. This figure is equivalent to 90 per cent of the total officer corps trained in Australia.

In response to the claims of the women at the peace camp, an ADI spokesperson who came out to speak to the media and refute the women's claims said ADI did not export ammunition to the Papua New Guinea defence forces. This ADI spokesperson has misled the Australian public. The work of Australian Humanitarian Aid for Bougainville has proved this by uncovering the truth about ADI's relationship with the Papua New Guinea defence force and the war in Bougainville.

AHAB has found that ADI's relationship with the Papua New Guinea defence force has been a `long one'. ADI's last two regional managers for Pacific international business both had regular contact with the PNGDF and made trips to Papua New Guinea to promote ADI weaponry. Papua New Guinea has close defence links with Australia, receiving millions of dollars in military aid every year. Since 1975, Australia has provided Papua New Guinea with $444 million in defence cooperation funds alone, which is a quarter of that program.

PNGDF gets arms from Australia in three ways: firstly, by the ADF from the defence cooperation program; secondly, via the ADF under supply support agreement; and, thirdly, straight from ADI. In the past, the defence cooperation agreement was how the PNGDF received Iroquois helicopters and Pacific class patrol boats from Australia. Most of Papua New Guinea's other defence equipment needs are supplied under supply support agreement.

The link between ADI, the Papua New Guinea defence force and ammunition is that ADI makes all the ammunition used by the ADF. Any ammunition that ADF sells to Papua New Guinea is made by ADI. Last year, the Papua New Guinea defence force bought ammunition directly from ADI. However, standard practice when PNG requests ammunition is for ADI to sell the ammunition to the ADF, which then on-sells it to the Papua New Guinea defence force. This process ensures ADI's name can be clear of the deal with the Papua New Guinea defence force and still earn the profits.

Another deal that ADI is into is selling Papua New Guinea rifles. ADI makes the Steyr rifles at its factory in Lithgow, New South Wales. Due to this contract ending this year, ADI is looking for new markets to sell the rifle, including to the Thai and Indonesian defence forces, both of which are known for their frequent human rights violations. The Papua New Guinea defence force is now in the process of upgrading its small arms.

The association that I was talking about, AHAB, has found that ADI has sent a number of Steyr rifles to Papua New Guinea for the Papua New Guinea Defence Forces to trial. ADI representatives have also been in Papua New Guinea promoting the Steyr rifle. The Australian Defence Force is encouraging the Papua New Guinea Defence Force to buy its new rifles from ADI. Clearly, the relationship between ADI and the Papua New Guinea Defence Force is a lot closer than ADI is prepared to admit to the Australian people!

What else does ADI sell to Papua New Guinea? It sells ADI grenades which the government claims are not technically landmines. ADI has already sent samples of its range of hand grenades to the Papua New Guinea Defence Force which already has the new F1 model. There is evidence to suggest that these grenades have been used by the Papua New Guinea Defence Force on Bougainville. The grenades can be detonated by pressure activation, pressure release, by trip wire and also by remote delivery such as from an ADI Steyr rifle. These alternative ways of detonation actually class these so-called grenades as technically landmines under protocol II of the United Nations Convention of Prohibitions or Restrictions on the use of certain Conventional Weapons which may be deemed to be Excessively Injurious or to have Indiscriminate Effects. No wonder our Minister for Foreign Affairs (Senator Gareth Evans) was coy about Australia actually banning such things.

I repeat that ADI is a government owned enterprise and we see these incredible hypocrisies with ADI manufacturing weapons against its own policies of working internationally to ban landmines and to stop their proliferation in wars in our region. The government knows that millions of landmines keep the war going for civilians long after a conflict has ended. This is especially the case for people living in agrarian societies who must return to the land to retain their way of life and their livelihoods. PNG and Bougainville is one such example.

So how does ADI transfer its arms to PNG? When they travel by sea, they travel with shipping companies Pacific Forum Line and Chief Container Services. When the arms and munitions travel by air, they go by the C130 Hercules aircraft on training flights to PNG, or on Qantas or Air New Guinea.

The Australian government must face up to its lack of dignity and ethics by stopping ADI's role in arming PNG against Bougainville. The government cannot wriggle out of its responsibilities to stop being an arms supplier in the region by selling off the arms manufacturer. The government must instead meet this problem head-on and stop the export of arms and ammunition from ADI. There is no purpose to this export of arms and ammunition except to make Australia money and we can do this without dirty money. If ADI is privatised, and it will be because it is only a matter of time, this unethical behaviour will have no checks and balances on the part of the government and the Australian people apart from the normal commercial export defence practices which, as we know, are very flawed, and exports to our region will continue to grow.

We will see more Steyr rifle deals to Thailand, to the Khmer Rouge, to Indonesia to suppress dissent in East Timor, Aceh and West Papua. We will basically see the extension and acceleration of the government's existing unethical policy of arms sales to the region within the very poor framework of ineffective arms control through the customs and defence export guidelines regimes. This organisation, AHAB, has clearly stated how Australia is arming the war on Bougainville. It is now up to the government to do something to stop it.
